text.title: The words of Jeremiah son of Hilkiah:

pasuk.text: Let the son of the corrupt woman, whose deeds are properJeremiah was descended from Rahab the harlotand let him reprove the son of the righteous woman whose deeds are corrupt these are Israel who corrupted their deeds who are descended from legitimate seed.

text.title: To whom the word of the Lord came:

pasuk.text: Upon whom the Shechinah commenced to rest at that time.

text.title: And he was in the days of Jehoiakim:

pasuk.text: And he was a prophet all the remaining days of Josiah, the days of his son Jehoiakim, and the days of his son Zedekiah, until the end of the eleventh yearthat is the yearuntil the exile of Jerusalem in the fifth month.

text.title: When I had not yet formed you in the womb, etc.:

pasuk.text: Since the days of the first man. The Holy One, blessed be He, showed Adam each generation and its prophets.
Heb. אצרך, an expression of צורה, a form.
connois toi in O.F. Comp. (Exodus 6:3), “I was not known (נודעתּי) to them.”
I appointed you for this.

To Israel, who behave like the nations. In this manner it is expounded in Sifrei on the verse: “A prophet from your midst, etc.” (Deut. 18:15), will set up for you and not for those who deny the Torah. How then do I fulfill “A prophet to the nations I made you” ? To the children of Israel who deport themselves with the customs of the nations. It can further be interpreted: “A prophet for the nations,” like “About the nations,” to give them to drink the cup of poison, to prophesy retribution upon them, as it is said: “Take this cup of the wine of wrath from My hand, you shall give all the nations to drink of it” (infra 25:15). Another explanation of “When you had not yet emerged from the womb I appointed you” is: Concerning you I said to Moses: “I will set up a prophet… like you” (Deut. 18:18). This one reproved them, and this one reproved them. This one prophesied for forty years and this one prophesied for forty years.
This is an expression of wailing (konpljjnt in 0.F.).

I am not worthy to reprove them. Moses reproved them shortly before his death, when he was already esteemed in their eyes through the many miracles that he had performed for them. He had taken them out of Egypt, split the Reed Sea for them, brought down the manna, caused the quails to fly, given them the Torah, brought up the well. I come to reprove them at the beginning of my mission.
to the heathens.
to Israel, you shall speak.

text.title: And the Lord stretched forth His hand:

pasuk.text: Every sending mentioned concerning a hand is an expression of stretching forth. Another explanation is like the Targum: And the Lord sent the words of His prophecy.
I have appointed you over the heathens.
(depayser in French, to uproot) and over Israel to build and to plant if they heed. So did Jonathan paraphrase it.

text.title: a rod of an almond tree:

pasuk.text: (amendleer in O.F.) Jonathan, however, renders: A King who hastens to do evil.

This almond tree hastens to blossom before all other trees. I, too, hasten to perform My word. And the Midrash Aggadah (Ecc. Rabbah 12:8) explains: An almond tree takes twenty-one days from its blossoming until it is completely ripe, as the number of days between the seventeenth of Tammuz, when the city was broken into, until the ninth of Ab, when the Temple was burnt.
[lit. blown up,] seething (boillant in French).
[lit. and its face,] its seething (et ses ondes in O.F.) [and its waves].

text.title: From the north the misfortune will break forth:

pasuk.text: Babylon is on the north of Eretz Israel.

text.title: And I will utter My judgments against them:

pasuk.text: I will debate with them, with Judah and Jerusalem.

text.title: And you shall gird your loins:

pasuk.text: This is an expression of quickening like a man of valor.
lit. to the Kings of Judah.

text.title: And they shall fight against you:

pasuk.text: They shall quarrel and fight against you to refute the words of your prophecy.

Were you to return to Me, I would desire to have mercy on you for I remember the loving kindness of your youth and the love of the nuptials of your wedding canopy, when I brought you into the wedding canopy, and this (כלולתיך) is an expression of bringing in. Your nuptials (Noces in O.F.). Now what was the loving kindness of your youth? Your following My messengers, Moses and Aaron, from an inhabited land to the desert without provisions for the way since you believed in Me.
like terumah.
Like the first of the harvest before the Omer, which it is forbidden to eat, and whoever eats it is liable, so will all those who eat him be guilty. So did Jonathan render it.

text.title: And they did not say, Where is the Lord:

pasuk.text: that we should follow other gods?
Heb. ערבה (planure in O.F.), related to pianoro in Old Italian, meaning ‘a plateau.’
Heb. ושוחה (enfosses in O.F.), pitted.
Heb. ציה (degat in French).
Heb. וצלמות. An expression of darkness.
To the land of Israel which is planted like כרמל, meaning: planted like a forest.

text.title: and those who hold onto the Torah:

pasuk.text: The Sanhedrin.
the kings.
In the name of Baal.
Before I bring misfortune upon you, I will still contend with you through My prophets, although I have already contended with you many days.
To the isles of the Kittites. איי is (isles in French).
And send to Kedar to see their custom.
And put your heart to it to consider the matter diligently.

Heb. הן, like אם, if. Whether either of those nations exchanged its god although they are no gods, yet My nation exchanged their glory, with which they were honored. The Kittites and the Kedarites were tent dwellers and cattle herders, who would travel, go, and wander from pasture to pasture and from desert to desert, and they carry their gods with them to the place where they encamp. But I carried you until I established you, yet you forsook Me. This is how Jonathan paraphrased it. Our Sages said however: The Kittites worshipped water and the Kedarites worshipped fire. And although they know that water quenches fire, they did not forsake their god.
For an idol that does not avail.
Heb. שמו, an expression of astonishment, like השתוממוּ. It is the imperative form, with the same vowel points as (I Sam. 14:9): “If they say thus to us,” Wait (דּמּוּ)."
Heb. ושערו, an expression of סער, a storm.
As though you are becoming desolate because of the Temple that is destined to be destroyed.

Had they exchanged their Deity [lit. their fear] for one His equal, it would be one evil, and now that they have forsaken Me, that I am a spring of living waters, to follow idols, which are like cisterns of stored up water, and they are broken and cracked, and their water is absorbed in their cracks, these are two evils.
Heb. לחצב, lit. to hew.
(Tendront in O.F.) their water, for the water will make their edge and their walls muddy, and they cave in.

text.title: Is he a home born slave?:

pasuk.text: The son of a maidservant.
roar, a present tense.
Symbolic of kings.
were burnt with fire.

text.title: Also the children of Noph and Tahpanhes:

pasuk.text: They are the Egyptians upon whom you trust for aid.
They will break your skull. ירעוּך is an expression of breaking (רציצה), as we translate ורצוץ, “and crushed” (Deut. 28:33), וּרעיע.

text.title: Is not this caused to you:

pasuk.text: Is not this misfortune and this retribution caused to you by the guilt and the iniquity that you have forsaken the Lord your God?

text.title: at the time He leads you by the way:

pasuk.text: For He would teach you the good and the straight way.

text.title: what have you to do in the way of Egypt:

pasuk.text: Why do you leave Me and trust in Egypt?

text.title: to drink the water of the Shihor:

pasuk.text: For they drowned your male children in the Nile. Shihor is the Nile, as it is said: “From the Shihor which is before Egypt,” in the Book of Joshua (13:3).

text.title: and what have you to do:

pasuk.text: to rebel against Me so that you should be exiled to the way of Assyria, to the other side of the Euphrates River?
Eventually, your evil will bring suffering upon you.
, Heb. ומשבותיך, an expression related to “backsliding children (שובבים)” (infra 3:22).
Heb. תוכחך, an expression of reproof.

text.title: and the fear of Me was not:

pasuk.text: My fear was not in your heart that you should fear Me.
To the wooden yoke an expression of breaking applies, and to the yoke-bands which are of leather an expression of tearing open applies.
[מוסרותיך are the] ropes used to shackle the yoke [to the animal].

text.title: and you said, “I will not transgress.”:

pasuk.text: your words.
Put you did not keep your promise, for on every lofty hill you recline (צעה). This is an expression of a bed and a sheet (מצע). [The word] כי serves as an expression of ‘but.’

text.title: I planted you a noble vine stock:

pasuk.text: Heb. שורק is the branches of a good vine, that is to say the children of pious and righteous fathers. Its midrashic interpretation is: I planted you שורק. I added for you to the seven commandments of the children of Noah, six hundred and six, as is the numerical value of שורק.
Heb. סוּרי (Destoultours in O.F).
that grows in the forests.
A type of earth with which garments are cleansed and rubbed.
Heb. בֹּרִית, cleanliness. Comp.“And pure (וּבַר) of heart” (Ps. 24:4). Some explain בֹּרִית as savon in French, soap.
Jon. renders: Like the mark of a stain that is unclean, so have your sins increased before Me. כתם is tka in O.F.

This is said concerning the iniquity of the ‘Golden Calf,’ which remains in existence forever, as it is stated: “And on the day of My visitation, I will visit upon them their sin” (Exodus 32:34). All visitations that come upon Israel have part of the iniquity of the Golden Calf in them.

text.title: See your way in the valley:

pasuk.text: See what you have done opposite Beth-Peor, and until now you adhere to that way like a swift she camel clinging to her ways.

Heb. בכרה, a young female camel, that loves to wander.“The young camels (בכרי) of Midian” (Isa. 60:6) is translated “and they are young camels,” as we find in Sanhedrin 52a: There are many old camels laden with the skins of young camels (הוגני).

Adhering to the ways of her youth, an expression similar to: “it would have clung (מסריך סריך)” (Chullin 51a). This may be associated with “a shoe thong נעל) (שרוך ” (Gen. 14:23). She binds the ways of her youth in her heart.
(salvatico in O.F.) wild, and some interpret it as poulain in O.F., a foal.
Accustomed to be in the deserts, so she loves to wander.
She opens her mouth and snuffs up the wind, and he always returns to his place.

text.title: her tendency like the sea creatures, who can hinder her?:

pasuk.text: That trait of the sea creatures that she has, for also the sea creature snuffs up the wind, as it is said: “They snuff up the wind like sea creatures” (infra 14:6). Who can hinder her from that trait? So it is with you who can return you from your evil way?

text.title: her tendency like a sea creature:

pasuk.text: Son dagronemant in O.F., dragon nature. Jonathan rendered it in this manner, כערודה. Another explanation: It is an expression of wailing, comp.“moaning and wailing”

text.title: all who seek her will not weary:

pasuk.text: For they will weary needlessly, for they will be unable to overtake her. What will her end be? In her month, they will find her. There is one month in the year that she sleeps for the whole month, and then she is captured. You, too, - one month (viz. Ab) was already prepared for you from the days of the spies, when your forefathers established it as a time of vain weeping, therein, you will be captured. (תּאניה ואניה) (Lam. 2:5). Another explanation: (sa contree in French,) her country, comp. Taanath Shiloh (Josh. 16:6).

text.title: Withhold your foot from going barefoot:

pasuk.text: This your habit, like the wild donkey that loves to wander. My prophets say to you, “Withhold your foot from idolatry lest you go barefoot into exile and withhold your throat from dying of thirst.”
concerning the words of the prophets.
It is of no concern. I despair of your words. נואש is (nonkalajjr in O.F.) nonchalair in modern French.
At the beginning, when he is found to be a thief, and he was presumed to be faithful. In this manner, Jonathan rendered it.

text.title: and at the time of their misfortune they say:

pasuk.text: i.e., they say to Me, “Arise and save us.” Jonathan, too, translates in this manner: And at the time that misfortune befalls them, they deny their idols and confess before Me, and say. “Have mercy upon us and save us.”

text.title: as many as your cities were your gods:

pasuk.text: In every city was another god.
How do you come to contend with the quarrel and say, “We do not sin” ?

text.title: All of you have rebelled against Me:

pasuk.text: Even the righteous are meant. This is what people say, “With the thorn the cabbage suffers.”
For no purpose, for it did not avail that they should receive correction.
your prophets, Zechariah and Isaiah.

text.title: See the word of the Lord:

pasuk.text: He took out to them the jar of manna. He said to them, “See here how helpful the word of the Lord is.”

text.title: was I a desert to Israel:

pasuk.text: Heb. המדבר. This is the interrogative form. Therefore, the ‘mem’ is punctuated ‘weak,’ i.e., without a ‘dagesh’ and the ‘heh’ with a ‘hataph-pattah.’ Did it seem to your forefathers that it was a desert when they traversed it? For I brought down for them this bread, the necessity of each day in its day.
מאפליה, an expression of darkness.

text.title: Why have My people said, “We have been separated…” ?:

pasuk.text: Heb. רדנו, we have been separated from You. Like one who separates (רודֶה) bread from the oven. So is the midrash of Rabbi Tanhuma (Bamidbar 2). Menahem, however, explains רדנוּ as an expression of descending (ירידה) and also in other manners (Machbereth Menahem, p. 162).
Heb. תיטבי. You adorn yourself to greet your adulterers. Comp.“And she adorned her head” (I Kings 9:30) concerning Jezebel in the section dealing with Jehu.

text.title: even to the most evil you accustomed:

pasuk.text: You searched throughout all the evil ways to learn the most corrupt of them all. גם is an expression of ‘even.’
Heb. לכן, an expression of a true oath. Verily, to the most evil way of all the ways you accustomed yourself.
Heb. למדת, lit. you taught.

text.title: you did not find them breaking in:

pasuk.text: You did not find them breaking in when you slew them.
So does Scripture say for a feminine second person singular, and there are many such examples in the Book of Ezekiel (16:58), “You bore them (נשאתים).”
i.e., because they were reproving you for all these things.
i.e., you said in your heart.
That I have purified my soul.
I will come with you in judgment.
Heb. תזלי, an expression of degradation.
To leave Me and to rely on Egypt for aid in the days of Jehoiakim and Zedekiah (infra 37).
Heb. לשנות, an expression of change.

text.title: as you were ashamed through Assyria:

pasuk.text: Upon whom Ahaz relied and “he oppressed him and did not strengthen him” (II Chron. 28:20).
I have to say that you are no longer fit for me, for so is the way of one who sends away his wife and she goes away, etc.

text.title: But you have played the harlot [with] many lovers:

pasuk.text: With many lovers. Nevertheless, return to Me.
Heb. ושוב, lit. and to return to me, like עשות, to do, and to return to Me, I long for you.
rivulets of water.
Heb. שלגת, an expression of a פילגש a concubine.
to be prepared to greet them.
A tent dweller, who is always found outside in the deserts, and because of this, he is called ערבי since he dwells in the ערבה, the plain.
The rain that falls in Nissan on the ears (מלילות) and the straws (קשים). מלקוש is (tardif in O.F.).
If only you repent of your evil and call me “My Father.” If you do so, will your Lord bear a grudge forever for what you have sinned? Will He keep it to eternity? He will not keep it.
with your mouth, “We will no longer come to You,” and that evil you will do, and you will not give any thought of returning.
And you prevailed in rebelling with a victorious and irrefutable reply.

text.title: In the days of King Josiah:

pasuk.text: when He commanded me to bring back the Ten Tribes,"Have you seen what the backsliding Israel has done? משבה is the same as שובבה, (envejjsede in O.F).
The Ten Tribes.
i.e., when she was still on her land before she was exiled in the days of Hezekiah with Hoshea son of Elah. הלכה means, she would go on every lofty mountain.

text.title: and she played the harlot there:

pasuk.text: i.e., she played the harlot by worshipping idols. וַתִּזְנִי is the equivalent of וַתִּזֶן, the ‘yod’ being superfluous.
through My prophets, Amos and Hosea son of Beeri and the other prophets, “You shall return to Me.”

text.title: And her treacherous sister Judah saw it:

pasuk.text: i.e., saw all this. The appellation “treacherous” is harsher than “backsliding.” Israel, since they were the first to sin, and they did not see any retribution from which to learn and to repent, are called “backsliding.” Judah, who saw that these went in exile and did not receive correction, are called “treacherous.”

text.title: And I saw, because of all that backsliding Israel had committed adultery:

pasuk.text: The signs of the intonation of this verse teach us its explanation. ישראל is punctuated with a ‘zakef-katan,’ separated from שלחתיה, I sent her away. שלחתיה, I sent her away, is punctuated with a ‘zakef-gadol’ by itself. And this is its explanation: I saw; i.e., I contemplated her to exact punishment upon her. And why? Because of all that backsliding Israel had committed adultery. And what was My vengeance? I sent her away from before Me. And treacherous Judah did not fear when she saw the retribution of Samaria, to set her heart to repent.

text.title: and she committed adultery with the stones:

pasuk.text: Jonathan paraphrases: And she strayed with the worshippers of stones and wood. And Jonathan renders מִקֹל as an expression of lightness, since her idols were light in her eyes.
that they saw the misfortune of the retribution of their companions.

Josiah’s generation would show themselves as righteous although they were wicked. They would make forms of pagan deities on the inside of their doors, half on this door and half on this one, and when the destroyers of idols would inspect, the door would be open, and they would not notice it.
She has been cleared and she has freed herself from an unfavorable verdict, for she had no one to learn from.

Go, as the Targum renders, אזיל, the imperative form. Here he commanded him to go and bring back the Ten Tribes during the days of Josiah, as he states above that during the days of Josiah this prophecy was said to him and some of them returned in the eighteenth year of Josiah.
To the places where they were exiled there to Assyria.
My anger, so did Jonathan render it.
Heb. פשעת.

text.title: and you have scattered your ways:

pasuk.text: This is an expression of harlotry, spreading the legs to the woman’s private parts.

(Envasec in O.F.) That you perverted your way because of much good, that you enjoyed tranquility and pleasure, as Scripture states: They hum snatches of song to the tune of the lute (Amos 6:5), those who drink from bowls of wine (v. 6).
and you are called by My name, that I am your Master, and it is not honorable for Me to leave you in the hands of My enemies.

text.title: they will no longer say, “The ark of the Lord’s covenant”:

pasuk.text: For your entire assembly will be holy, and I will dwell therein as though it were an ark.
Heb. יפקדו, like יזכרוּ, remember or mention.

text.title: nor shall it be done anymore:

pasuk.text: i.e., it shall not be done what was done with it already in Shiloh, that they brought it into the battle with the Philistines in the days of Eli.
Heb. ונקוו, an expression of: מקוה מים, a gathering of water.
an expression of seeing. Comp. אשורנו “I see him” (Num. 24:17).

text.title: the house of Judah will go with the house of Israel:

pasuk.text: They will join them and they will be added to them to be one kingdom.
to Myself, etc. and therefore, I caused your forefathers to inherit them.

text.title: How shall I place you among the sons?:

pasuk.text: i.e., how shall I place you, my congregation and My nation, among the other sons, mingled with the heathens. I, therefore, selected a handsome portion, and I gave you a desirable land.

text.title: the beauty of hosts of nations:

pasuk.text: The beauty of all the hosts of nations.

But you did not live up to My expectations [lit., do My thought], but like a woman who betrays her beloved because he cannot provide her sustenance, so did you betray Me, Who provides you with all good. So is the Midrash Aggadah (Tanhuma Mishpatim 17).

text.title: A voice on the rivulets is heard:

pasuk.text: It is likely to be heard.

text.title: Here we are, we have come to You:

pasuk.text: The prophet teaches them to confess and to say as follows, “Here we are, we have come to You… Truly, in vain… But the shameful thing has consumed, etc., Let us lie in our shame.” All this is the language of the prayer that the prophet teaches them to say. We have come אתנו.
we awaited from the hills and the multitude of mountains where we worshipped idols.
in truth.
The idolatry with which we occupied ourselves, as Scripture states.“And they turned aside to the shameful thing” (Hosea 9:10).

text.title: consumed the toil of our fathers:

pasuk.text: Because of the iniquity of its worship, our toil was pillaged.
with this repentance, to Me, you will return to your original glory and greatness.

text.title: and if you remove your detestable things from My Presence:

pasuk.text: Then you shall not wander to go out in exile.

text.title: And you will swear, “As the Lord lives,” in truth:

pasuk.text: When you swear by My name, you will swear in truth, not as now, that it is written concerning you, “And if they say, ‘As the Lord lives,’ surely they swear falsely” (5:2).

text.title: nations will bless themselves with him:

pasuk.text: If you do so, then nations will bless themselves with Israel. Every non-Jew will say to his son, “You shall be like So-and-so the Jew.”
Heb. יתהללו, they will recite your praise. Another explanation of is יתהללו : Whoever is able to cleave to Israel will boast about the matter (porvanter in French).

text.title: For so said the Lord, etc. Plow for yourself a furrow:

pasuk.text: Learn from the tillers of the soil, who plow it in the summer to kill the roots of the grasses, that it should not grow thorns at the time of sowing in the winter. You, too, improve your deeds before the evil befalls you, so that your prayer should not be rejected when you cry out.

text.title: and do not sow upon thorns:

pasuk.text: And let not your cry before Me be from amidst wickedness, but from amidst repentance, that you shall not resemble one sowing without plowing, and that turns into thorns (kardons in O.F., chardons in modern French).
Before My anger comes forth like fire. This is like plowing before the sowing.
Warn the inhabitants of the land that they sound the shophar to flee.

Heb. מלאו. An expression of gathering, and there are many in the Scriptures: (Isaiah 31: 4) “Although a band of (מְלֹא) shepherds gather against him,” Also (infra 12:6) “They called after you a band (מָלֵא).” Also (Job 16: 10) “Together they gather (יתמלאוּן) against me.”
to flee to Zion.
Heb. העיזו. Comp.“Send, gather (העז)” (Exodus 9:19).
That is Nebuchadnezzar.
It is customary for a lion to lie in wait in the thickets of the forest (espaises in O.F.).
Heb. תצינה, an expression of desolation.
What is “this?” “For the fierce anger etc.” Although he spoke above concerning Nebuchadnezzar in regards to the destruction, here he returns to speak of the death of Josiah.

text.title: for the fierce anger of the Lord etc.:

pasuk.text: Although Josiah repented wholeheartedly, it is stated concerning him. (II Kings 23:26)…“the Lord did not turn back from his great wrath… because of all the provocations that Manasseh had provoked Him.”

text.title: And it shall be on that day:

pasuk.text: On the day of Josiah they will wonder why so much befell him, for they do not know that his generation did not repent properly. When he came to abolish idolatry, what did the scorners of the generation do? They would engrave an image of a pagan deity on their doors, half of it on this door and half of it on this door. When he would open it, it was not discernible, and when he went away from there, he would close it, and it would join together.
Heb. השא השאת (fa)tenter in O.F.), tempting, an expression like (Gen. 3:13) “The serpent misled me (השיאני),” for the false prophets prophesy for them, You will have peace.
Concerning this people when they are all exiled.
It sweeps even the fields with rivulets of water to make them into a desert. Another explanation: צח is an expression of thirst, which is translated צחותא.

text.title: [on] the way of the daughter of My people:

pasuk.text: That wind will come, and also, not to winnow the chaff from the threshing floor ([a] vanner in O.F.). Comp. (infra 15:7) “And I winnowed them with a sieve במזרה) (ואזרם.”
And not to cleanse grain does it come. That is to say, not for good but for evil, to exile men [women], and children, and livestock.
of these retributions shall come to me.
A full spirit, that I will not retract and not repent.
(talant in O.F.)
Heb. משפטים, an expression of debating.
(comme tourbillon in O.F.)
Your injustice.

text.title: For a voice proclaims from Dan:

pasuk.text: Jonathan paraphrases: “Behold the voice of the prophets prophesy about them that they will be exiled because they worshipped the calf that was in Dan, and people bringing bad tidings will come upon them because they subordinated themselves to the image that Micah erected on the mountain of the house of Ephraim.” Although the calves had already been exiled since the days of Sennacherib, their iniquity was still existing. Sin is harsh, for it destroys [lit. breaks] before it and after it; before it, since the days of Abraham, as it is stated (Gen. 14:14): “And he pursued until Dan.” As soon as he reached Dan, he grew faint [lit. his strength was weakened], for his children would, in the future, worship idols there, and after it, in the destruction of the Temple, as it is stated: “A voice proclaims from Dan.”
Heb. און, a breach.
Heb. נצרים. Those who will make a siege upon them.
like שדה, a field.

text.title: for she has rebelled against me:

pasuk.text: She has provoked Me. Comp. (Deut. 9:24) “You have been rebellious (ממרים),” provoking.
To do these to you.
Heb. אוחילה. An expression of writhing in pain (חיל) and shuddering.
(ettancon in O. F.), blocking wall, perhaps from late Latin, intimus, innermost.
From behind the curtain of heaven the ridings of the sound of the alarm of war reached me.
The destruction of Jerusalem upon the exile of Jeconiah.
In a moment my curtains were plundered.
these groups carrying the standard to come to wage war.
Heb. התקלקלו, they were uprooted and cast out of their place. Menahem associates it with: “He shakes the arrows to and fro (קלקל) ” (Ezek. 21:26).

The land, planted with all good like a forest, has become like a desert. The Midrash Aggadah states: “I saw the mountains” These are the Patriarchs. “And all the hills” These are the Matriarchs. That is to say that their merit was depleted. “There were no people” This refers to Moses, about whom it is said: “humbler than all the people” (Num. 12:3).“And behold the Karmel” This is Elijah.

text.title: but I will not make an end:

pasuk.text: of its inhabitants, for I will leave over refugees who will go into exile.
Shall be destroyed.
Heb. זמתי, an expression of thought.
i.e., this retribution, and I will fulfill it.

text.title: and I will not turn back:

pasuk.text: And I will not repent to think good thoughts about them.
Heb. רמה קשת, lit. bow shooters. Comp.“Cast (רמה) into the sea” (Exodus 15:1).
Into the thick forests, a place intertwined with thorns, to hide.

text.title: and they ascended among the boulders:

pasuk.text: Heb. ובכפים. סלע, a rock, is translated into Aramaic as בכפיא.
to beautify yourself and to gain clemency before the plunderer.
Heb. תקרעי. An expression of tearing, for the paint appears as widening the opening of the eye. So have I heard, and Menahem did not differentiate in the group of קרע.
Heb. בפוך, an expression of a blue paint.
Heb. עגבים, those who jest with the women with various types of adultery. Comp. (Ezekiel 23:20) “She lusted (ותעגבה) for concubinage with them.”
They seek to kill you.

text.title: like a woman bearing her first child:

pasuk.text: Heb. כמבכירה, like a woman bearing her first child, the beginning of her birth.
Heb. תתיפח, she will wail and cry out with sighs (konpljjnt in O.F:). Comp.“who speak (ויפח) violence” (Psalms 27:12), an expression of speech.
This is what she says.
are they not on people with faith, to do good to them? Now why have these betrayed You, and they do not seek faith?
and they did not become ill because of the blow to lay it to their heart to repent of their evil.
Heb. קחת, equivalent to (לקחת) , to receive.
The prophet says so, “They are but impoverished of wisdom,” these with whom I speak.
Heb. נואלו, an expression of אויל, a fool, as the Targum renders: אטפשו.

text.title: I will go to the great ones:

pasuk.text: They will hearken. But I did not avail, and they too together broke the yoke of the Holy One, blessed be He, off them.
The kingdom of Babylon.
The kingdom of Media.
The kingdom of Greece.
by Edom.
Heb. ערבות, an expression of (supra 2:6) ערבה ושוחה“plains and pits,” a wolf of the desert.
Heb. שקד. Menahem (p. 180) associates it with an expression of watching. Comp. (Prov. 8:34) “To watch (לשקוד) My doors daily.” And Jonathan rendered it as an expression of lying in wait.

text.title: Shall I forgive you for this?:

pasuk.text: This is the rhetorical question, Shall I forgive you for this? And Menahem (p. 22) explains אי like אין, not. For this I will not forgive you, because your children have forsaken Me, when I sated them with all good.
They gather in troops.

text.title: Like armed stallions they would arise early:

pasuk.text: Like these stallions who are armed with erect membra, every morning they would arise at daybreak.
Heb. יצהלו. This too is an expression appropriate for horses. Comp. (8:16) “From the sound of the neighing (מצהלות) of his steeds,” an expression of shouting (esjodement in O.F.).

Heb. בשרותיה, an expression of a plain. Menahem (p. 181) associates it as an expression of a wall with (II Sam. 22: 30) “I scale a wall (שור),” but נטישותיה (cep in Prov.) do not fitfor they are the roots of the vineyard to be associated either with the walls or with the plain. I say, therefore, that בשרותיה is an expression of the rows of the vineyard. Jonathan, however, rendered בשרותיה, in her cities, and נטישותיה, her palaces.
[The Targum renders:] Our good fortune does not come before Him.

text.title: And the prophets shall become wind:

pasuk.text: As the Targum renders: And the false prophets shall become naught. That is to say, the prophecy that the false prophets prophesy for us in the name of the Holy One, blessed be Hetheir words shall turn to futility, and the speech of holiness that they say to us in the name of the Holy One, blessed be He, is not in them.

text.title: So shall be done to them:

pasuk.text: The prophet says to those who say this, “So shall be done to them as the Lord said to me, and what did the Lord say to me?” Because you have spoken this word, etc."
Heb. ואכלתם.
Heb. איתן, strong.
From days of yore it began to rebel against Me, in the generation of separation in the land of Shinar.
Heb. אשפתו. The place of the arrow case.

text.title: He will impoverish your fortified cities [upon which you rely, with the sword]:

pasuk.text: This verse is in the wrong order [and should be arranged as follows:] He will impoverish with the sword your fortified cities upon which you rely.
Heb. ירשש, he will impoverish.
With troops. Comp.“And a sword will not pass in your land” (Lev. 26:6).
Does not the sea, which is not concerned about retribution and does not look forward to receiving reward, fear Me and not cross the boundary that I set around it?
Heb. תחילו, an expression of fear.
i.e., its waves, and they lift themselves to cross the border but cannot cross.
A loud sound of roaring.

text.title: but they do not pass it:

pasuk.text: The waves do not pass the border.

text.title: the early rain and the latter rain:

pasuk.text: Heb. יורה ומלקוש, as the Targum renders: בכיר ולקיש, the early rain and the latter rain.

text.title: the weeks of the laws of harvest:

pasuk.text: Seven weeks in which He ordained two ordinances of harvest, the ordinance of the omer, and the ordinance of the two breads.
that the harvest should be in its time.
Have brought about these laws. Have cast aside these laws from you, so they don’t guard you and you will be consumed from hunger.
Heb. ישור. Comp. למען שוררי because of those who lie in wait for me (Psalms 27: 11), an expression of “I see him (אשורנו) but not near” (Num. 24:17).
As a trap that they make to catch deer in the forest, bites when his foot enters it and it bites him and holds onto his foot and he is caught, and the call this (piege in O. F.).
(Canbel in O. F.) So do those who lie in wait make for a city or on the road.
Heb. יציבו, like “the garrison (מצב) of the Philistines” (I Sam. 14:4).
That is a place where they fatten fowl, and so does Jonathan render it, like a fattening place, and in O.F. (frank).
Heb. עשתו, an expression of “a block (עֶשֶת) of ivory” (Song 5:14), a thick body, and in O.F. enboeront.

text.title: they transgressed in deeds of wickedness:

pasuk.text: If evil or a sin came into their hand, they did not turn away from it, but transgressed it and committed it.

text.title: they did not plead the cause of the orphan:

pasuk.text: in order that they prosper.
Heb. שמה, a wonder.

Heb. ושערורה, a disgraceful thing to all, and what is the appalling thing? The prophets prophesy falsely and say, “Rob and plunder,” and the priests, who are the judges of the people and their overseers, govern the people on the hands of the prophets, that is to say, after them. Comp. (II Sam. 15) “And the king was crossing and all the people were crossing on his hand,” stated concerning David, meaning ‘after him.’ Here too, “on their hands” means ‘after them,’ to do according to the words of the prophets.
to go to their cities to guard their fortifications.
That is a place name.
a standard to gather and fight for your lives.

text.title: The comely and the delicate one have I destroyed:

pasuk.text: Heb. דמיתי. Jonathan renders it as an expression related to (25:37) “And the dwellings of peace shall be destroyed (ונדמוּ).” Also (47: 5), “Ashkelon has been destroyed (נדמתה).”
Figurative of kings and their armies.
Heb. רעו, they eat.
Heb. ידו [lit. his hand.] His place around him.
Heb. קדשו.
at the time the day declines.
When it declined to eventide, they ignited the Temple.

Heb. עצה. This is not a ‘mappiq heh,’ yet it is an expression of a tree (עץ), for the expression of cutting is not appropriate for advice, (עצה), and עצה mentioned here is an expression of many trees, as דגה is an expression of many fish.

text.title: the city whose sins have been visited upon her:

pasuk.text: Heb. הפקד, whose visitation has come.
Heb. כהקיר, an expression of a spring.
Heb. בַּיִר, equivalent to בְּאֵר.

text.title: so has she let her evil flow:

pasuk.text: So does their evil flow, constantly increasing and renewing.
Therefore, I brought upon her sickness and wounds.
Heb. הוסרי. Accept correction.

Heb. תקע, lest it be pulled away. יקע is an expression of joining. Comp.“and hang them up (והוקע)” (Num. 25:4), and it is sometimes an expression of detaching. There are many words that are used in such a manner.
(grappiller in French). After the vineyard has been gathered, and gleanings are left, and the poor come and glean them, so will they spoil and return and spoil.

You, the enemy, return your hand to spoil a second time, like a vintager who returns his hand for the search, who looks and searches for the gleanings. And so it was when he exiled Jehoiakim and slew him, and crowned Jeconiah, he returned three months later and exiled him. He returned eleven years later and exiled Zedekiah.

Heb. סלסלות (reverchedures in O.F). Comp. (Prov. 4:8) “Search for it (סלסלה) and it will exalt you.” So did Dunash (Teshuvoth Dunash p. 21) explain it. Menahem (Machbereth p. 126), however, explains it as an expression of a basket (סל) (paniers in O. F. baskets).
Heb. ואעידה, an expression of warning.
Heb. ערלה, clogged, and so is every expression of ערלה.
They deride it.

text.title: Therefore, I am full of the fury of the Lord:

pasuk.text: My heart is full of the prophecy of the coming of the fury of the Lord upon them.
Heb. הכיל, like להכיל, to contain ([a] souffrir in O.F.), to tolerate.

text.title: to pour it out upon the babes:

pasuk.text: to pour it upon the sucklings.
in the market.
i.e., one close to death, older than ‘an old man.’
shall be turned over to others.
rob money.
It is easy for the false prophets to pronounce with their mouths and to say, “You shall have peace,” and with this thing they heal with their speech the breach destined to come upon them.
Heb. הובישו, they should be ashamed [from Jonathan].
Heb. הכלים, like להכלים.
They are not ashamed of their evil deeds.
Heb. מרגוע.

text.title: And I have stationed lookouts over you:

pasuk.text: That is that they station men on the towers at the time of strife. A man looks and sees. If a troop is approaching the city he sounds a shophar and warns the people to arm and to come on the wall. I too appointed prophets who inform you about the impending retribution to alert yourselves and to mend your ways so that you be saved and that is like the shophar sounded by the lookout. Hearken to the sound of this shophar and arm yourselves.
Heb. והקמותי. This means: I have already stationed for them. And so did Jonathan render: ואקימית, and I stationed.
(Badetes in O.F.).
i.e., the evil that is in their hands.
the retribution for their thoughts.

Heb. וימאסו בה ותורתי. This follows the pattern of (Exodus 15:2) “The strength and destruction of God was my salvation (ויהי לי לישועה),” for he should have said: והיה לי לישועה. So too, here it should have said, ותורתי מאסו בה, but it is the style of Scripture to speak in this manner.
that you offer up to Me, that comes from Sheba?
Heb. ערבוּ.
Heb. יחזיקו, they will take. Comp. (Exodus 4:4) “And he stretched out his hand and took it (ויחזק).” Comp. also (infra verse 24) “trouble grasped us (החזיקתנוּ) held us.”
Heb. מגור. Another explanation: An expression of gathering. Comp. (Ezekiel 21:17) “Gathered (מגורי) to the sword.” And in this manner Jonathan renders it.
Heb. והתפלשי.

text.title: a mourning [as] for an only child:

pasuk.text: A mourning for an only son; one who has only one son and he dies.
Heb. תמרורים מספד. Since it is the construct state, it is vowelized מספד with a ‘pattah,’ and it is not vowelized מספד with a ‘tzere.’
So to speak, upon Me and upon you.

text.title: I have made you the strong one:

pasuk.text: This was said to Jeremiah. I have made you the strong one in their midst, and you shall know and test their way, that he tested them and they will not heed. בחון is an expression of strength. Comp. (Isa. 32:14) “rampart and tower (בחן) ,” also (ibid. 23: 13) “they erected its towers (בחוניו).”
Turning away from the road.

between copper and iron. They introduce hatred between two princes who have the power to provoke one another. That is what I heard. But I say, they are tale bearers, and they are as strong as copper and iron to maintain their falsehood. Jonathan, however, renders this word רכיל as an expression of guile (נוכל). They go with guile as one mixes copper with iron. נוכל is an expression of plot. Comp. (Gen. 37:18) “And they plotted (ויתנכלו) against him to slay him.”

This is an allegory. When they refine silver, they blow with a bellows, and they always put lead into the crucible, which helps for the refining. But youI have come to refine you. The bellows is heated and parched because of the fire, and the lead is completely consumed. נחר is an expression related to (Job 42:7) “My wrath has been kindled (חרה) ” ; (ibid. 30: 30) “And my bones are burned (חרה) with heat,” (esrast in O.F.).
In vain does the founder refine, for it is of no avail

text.title: and the wicked ones have not been separated:

pasuk.text: from their evil way. That is to say that the prophets toiled to reprove, but it did not avail them.
Heb. נתקו, (furent de… in O.F.). (Another version:) and the wicked ones. This is like רשעים.
which cannot be refined with any toil.

text.title: The Temple of the Lord, the Temple of the Lord, etc.:

pasuk.text: Three times a year you appear before Me.
This is a question. Will you do all these, and should the Temple of the Lord avail for you?

text.title: Has… a cave of profligate men?:

pasuk.text: Was this house in your eyes? This is a question.
that it is so in your eyes.
in the days of Eli.
the ten tribes.
Heb. כַּוָנִים, the shape of a star.
The largest star they would call מלכתהשמים, an expression of a queen, (מלכּה), and so did Jonathan render it: לכוכבתשמיא, to the female star of heaven.
Heb. נתכת, falls and reaches. Comp. (Exodus 9: 33) “and rain did not reach (נתּך) the earth” ; did not reach.

that you offer up completelyit would be better for you to add them to your peace-offerings and sacrifice them as peace-offerings and eat the flesh, for they are not acceptable before Me. Why, then, should you lose them?

text.title: on the day I brought them forth:

pasuk.text: The beginning of the condition was only (Exodus 19: 5): “If you hearken to My voice and keep My covenant, you shall be a peculiar treasure to Me.”
Heb. בשררות, in the view of their heart, an expression related to (Num. 24:17) “I see him אשורנו.”

text.title: sending them day [after day] every fresh morn:

pasuk.text: Every day sending them early.

Heb. נזרך גזי, tear out your hair. Comp. (Num. 11:31) “And He caused quails to fly (ויגז) ” ; also (Job 1:20), “And he shaved (ויגז) his head.” Another explanation is that נזרך means ‘your diadem,’ an expression of greatness, and so did Jonathan render: רברביך your great ones, and so did Menahem classify it (p. 83).
Heb. ויטש.

That is Molech, which was of copper, and they would heat it up from underneath it with its hands spread out and heated. And they would place the child on his hands, and he would be burnt and moan, and the priests would beat drums so that the father should not hear his son’s voice and take pity. It is called Topheth because of the drum (תּוף), Hinnom because of the child’s moaning (נהמת).
Because of the child’s moaning.

with commandments that they offer up their children as sacrifices, and I did not speak to any of the prophets, and when I did speak to Abraham to slaughter his son, it did not enter My mind that he slaughter, but only to make his righteousness known.

text.title: and no one will frighten them:

pasuk.text: i.e., no one will frighten the fowl from the carcasses.

text.title: And spread them before the sun:

pasuk.text: And the Chaldeans shall dwell when they besiege the city, in the graves of the princes, that were as beautiful as palaces.
For fertilizer.

text.title: And death shall be preferable to life:

pasuk.text: Although they see the dead being subjected to disgrace, the distress of the living is worse than that, and they will choose death.

text.title: Shall they fall and not rise:

pasuk.text: Is it good for them to cast themselves into a fall from which there is no rising?

text.title: if he repents, will He not return?:

pasuk.text: If they wish to repent of their wickedness, will the Holy One, blessed be He, not return from His decree? Another explanation: If they repent, the repentance will not be permanent, for they will quickly return to their wickedness, and in this manner Jonathan rendered it: If to repent, it is revealed before Me that they will not repent.
Heb. משבה נצחת, a perpetual backsliding, like נצח, perpetual.
Heb. החזיקו.
Heb. בתרמית.
Heb. לא כן, not right, cf. (Num. 27:7)"The daughters of Zelaphehad speak justly (כּן).

text.title: Each one turns away in his course:

pasuk.text: [lit. in their course.] In the first way. They sin and repeatedly sin. מרוצתם is korse in O.F.
effaye in French.
(Cigogne in French).
The time they pass to the islands of the sea because of the cold, and the time of their return.
Heb. שמרו.

text.title: and the turtledove and the crane and the swallow:

pasuk.text: Jonathan renders: ושפנינא וכורכיא וּסנוּניתא. כּורכיא is (grue in French), a crane. סנוּניתא is (hirondelle in French), a swallow.

text.title: Verily, behold it is in vain:

pasuk.text: Behold your wisdom is in vain within you to heal you lightly.

text.title: he made a false scribes’ pen:

pasuk.text: i.e., your prophet.
i.e., wise men like you. And what is the shame? Behold, they rejected the word of the Lord, now what wisdom have they?
Heb. וירפו, similar to וירפאו.

text.title: They shall be put to shame:

pasuk.text: Shame and embarrassment shall come upon them.
They are not ashamed of their evil deeds to take heart to repent.
This is an expression of destruction. Comp. (Zeph. 1:2) “I will utterly consume (אסף אסף) everything from upon the face of the earth.”

text.title: There shall be no grapes on the vine:

pasuk.text: Nothing will be left over.

text.title: even the leaves will be withered:

pasuk.text: Heb. נבל, an expression of withering (fleirit in French). Comp. (Isa. 34:4) “and as a withered fig (וּכנבלת) from a fig tree.” Also (ibid. 1:30), “like an elm whose leaves are wilting (נבלת).”

text.title: for what I gave them they transgressed:

pasuk.text: All this shall befall them because I gave them statutes and they transgressed them.

text.title: and there let us sit in silence:

pasuk.text: And let us be silent there. Let us sit there silent and mournful.
Jonathan renders: the cup of the curse, like the venom of serpents. The venom of the serpents is the poison that is in his teeth.
Because they worshipped the calf that was in Dan.
The sneezing of his nostrils.

The neighing of joy of his horses, and we find elsewhere that horses are called אבּירים (Jud. 5:22) by reason of the prancings, “the prancings of their mighty ones (אבּיריו) ,” an expression of (Nahum 3:2) “a prancing horse.” And Jonathan renders: from the sound of the steps of their mighty ones.

After seventy years, the snake becomes a צפע, which shuts its ear so that it will not hear the voice of the charmer who charms him, as it is stated (Psalms 58:5), “Like a deaf asp that shuts up its ear.” That is the meaning of “that cannot be charmed.”

text.title: Were I to suppress my grief:

pasuk.text: Heb. מבליגיתי, my suppression, and it is a noun, (mes estenimenc in O.F.). That is to say, if I said, I will suppress and keep in my grief.

text.title: my heart is sick within me:

pasuk.text: From the voice of the prophecies that are revealed to me of the coming retributions.

text.title: Hark the voice… the cry of the daughter of My people:

pasuk.text: I hear that eventually they will cry from a distant land, but why is all this necessary? Is not the Lord in Zion? If they return to Him, He will allow Himself to be found by them.

text.title: The harvest is past, the summer is ended:

pasuk.text: We looked forward to the aid of Egypt, but it did not come. We said, “Let the harvest pass, and they will be free, and they will come.” Now behold, the time of harvest has passed in Iyar, and the summer season in Tammuz, and they have not come.
lit. I am darkened, an expression of blackness and darkness.
Heb. שמה, wonder.
Has held me.

text.title: Is there no balm in Gilead:

pasuk.text: For balm comes from there, as it is said (infra 46: 11) “Go up to Gilead and take balm.” That is to say, Did they not have any righteous men from whom to learn so that they should improve their ways?
lit. the cure of, (emplatre in O. F.), plaster, dressing.
Companies of traitors.

Lit. trodden. This expression is appropriate for the preparation of the bow to shoot an arrow, and a bow (קשת) is (arbalete in French), and they tread it with their feet. Therefore, he calls it treading, and the prophet compared their tongue to a treacherous bow, for they directed their tongue like a treacherous bow.
From sin to sin.
He lays traps.

text.title: they commit iniquity [until] they are weary:

pasuk.text: They wearied themselves and toiled to pervert their way. העוה is like (Exod. 8: 11) “and making heavy (והכבּד) his heart,” to commit iniquity.

text.title: Your habitation is in the midst of deceit:

pasuk.text: When they sit, they devise plans of deceit, and with deceit they have exchanged fear of Me and refused to know Me.
Heb. בּמרמה.
with torments.

text.title: because of the daughter of My people:

pasuk.text: Because of the sins of the congregation of Israel.

text.title: Their tongue is a deadly arrow:

pasuk.text: Heb. שחוט, drawn. Comp. (I Kings 10: 16) “malleable gold” (שחוט). Also, (Hos. 5:2) “And the extent of their turning away (ושחטה),” (tirer in French), pulling. Another explanation is that it is actually an expression of slaughter (tranchant in French, cutting). In this manner Menahem classified it (Machbereth Menahem p. 172), and in this manner Jonathan rendered it: כּגיר די מחרף, like a sharpened arrow.
lit. in his midst. Jonathan renders: in his innards.
i.e., for the destruction of the mountains.

text.title: for the dwellings of the wilderness:

pasuk.text: The dwelling of the shepherds in the wilderness. נאות is an expression of a dwelling. Comp. (Psalms 83: 13) “the dwellings (נאות) of God,” also (ibid. 93:5) “to Your house, the dwelling (נאוה) of sanctity.”
Heb. נצתו. An expression of aridness. Comp. (v. 11) “withered (נצתה).”

i.e., they are destined to go. For fifty- two years no one passed through Judah; from the exile of Zedekiah until the order of Cyrus, king of Persia, were fifty-two years. An allusion to the matter [is that the numerical value for] “and the beast” (בּהמה) amounts to fifty-two, and the computation is exact, in Tractate Megillah [should read: Yoma 54a].
Heb. דגורין heaps.

text.title: Who is the man so wise:

pasuk.text: Who will understand this, and who is the prophet to whom the mouth of the Lord has spoken, that he may declare it? And who will declare why the land is ruined and all this retribution has come?
Bitter grass.
Snake venom.

text.title: they have cast down our dwellings:

pasuk.text: Heb. השליכו משכנותינו, [our dwellings] have cast out their inhabitants. We can also explain: For the enemies have cast our dwellings to the ground.
Heb. מחוץ, from the street. Comp. (I Kings 20:34) “And you shall make yourself streets in Damascus.”

text.title: Let not the wise man boast:

pasuk.text: Do not boast, saying, “We are wise.” Behold, you have rejected My words, so what wisdom do you have? If you understand and know Me, then you can boast of your wisdom.
Heb. השכיל, like (Exod. 8:11) “making heavy (הכבד)” (Enteliant in O. F.).

text.title: every circumcised one for his uncircumcision:

pasuk.text: Every circumcised one who has a foreskin, even an uncircumcised heart, and surely I will punish the heathens.
These were the neighbors of Eretz Israel, and they were punished shortly after her, as it is written in Ezekiel (29), and explained in Seder Olam (ch. 26).
Heb. פאה, an expression of an end, those cast off to the corner of the desert.

text.title: Of the way of the nations you shall not learn:

pasuk.text: Of the way of the nations you shall not learnand then, from the signs of the heavens you will not be dismayed, from the eclipse of the sun or the eclipse of the luminaries.
Heb. חרש, a craftsman.
Dolodojjre in O.F.
clous in French.
A hammer, marteau in French.
Heb. יפיק, it does not kneel with its knees. Comp. (I Sam. 25: 31) “a stumbling block (פוקה) ” ; (Nahum 2:11) “and tottering (ופיק) of the knees.”

text.title: Like a palm tree they are beaten:

pasuk.text: He hammers them with a hammer until it has an upright stature like a palm tree.
if you separate from them for they will not harm you.

text.title: neither is it in them to do good:

pasuk.text: If you worship them. היטיב is like להיטיב to do good.
It is proper for you.

text.title: But with one thing they are brutish:

pasuk.text: i.e., the heathens, and what is that one thing? Their vanities of wood for which they will be punished, and they will be punished for it. יבערו is an expression of foolishness, so is ויכסלו.
Heb. מרקע.

text.title: But the Lord God is true:

pasuk.text: Why? Because He is a living God and the King of the world. Therefore, He can make His words come true. A mortal person, however, plans to do something and dies or becomes weak or loses his property, and has no ability to execute his plans.

text.title: So shall you say to them:

pasuk.text: This is a letter that Jeremiah sent to Jeconiah and those exiled with him in exile, to reply to the Chaldees in Aramaic, a reply if they tell them to worship idols.
Tendre in French.

text.title: At the sound of His giving:

pasuk.text: At the time the sound comes that He is giving a multitude of water in the heavens.
Heb. נשאים, clouds.
plaindres in old French.
Heb. נבער. Comp. (Psalms 92:7) “a brutish (בער) man” ; also here (infra 10:21), “the shepherds have become brutish (נבערו).”
Heb. נסכו. An expression of מסכה, a molten image.

text.title: at the time of their visitation:

pasuk.text: When I will visit retribution upon them.

text.title: Gather in from the land your merchandise:

pasuk.text: Heb. כנעתך. Hide, gather in from the land your merchandise. Comp. (Hos. 12:8) “The trafficker (כּנען) in his hand are deceitful scales.” Menahem explains כנעתך as an expression of humility (הכנעה) and lowliness. And אספי is an expression of bending down. Bend down and humble yourself more than the lowliness of the earth, you Jerusalem, that dwells now in a fortified city (Machbereth p. 107).
as one slings a stone with a slingshot.
they may find their just deserts.
Heb. נחלה, an expression of sickness (חלי).
Heb. ואשאנו. Jonathan renders. And I will bear it ([a] souffrir lui in O. F.).
Heb. יצאוני, have left me, Jerusalem says this.
The kings.
They have not prospered in their kingdom. Comp. (Prov. 17:8)"To all that he turns, he will prosper (ישכיל).
Heb. מרעיתם, lit. their pasture, the flocks of their pasture.

For the evil inclination that You created in him leads him astray from the way. Another explanation is: I know, O Lord, that man’s way is not his; not every man has the power to make his way prosper, and if it were not for Your command, the enemy would have no power to destroy Your Temple.
With chastisements.
(justice in French).
Jonathan renders: but with mild judgment.
lest there be complete destruction.
(devorerent in French). The same applies to “and consumed him” (ואכלהוּ).
that he be cursed.
Heb. העידתי, an expression of warning.

text.title: And I brought upon them all the words of this covenant:

pasuk.text: The curses stated in the covenant for the things that I commanded to do and they did not do.

text.title: And they shall go the cities of Judah:

pasuk.text: From the cities of Judah.
This follows the Targum.

text.title: What has my beloved to do in My house:

pasuk.text: What reason has My treasured people to come anymore into My house?
That she does the evil design of her sinful plans.
of them.

text.title: and the holy flesh they remove from you:

pasuk.text: Even the circumcision through which they were hallowed to Me, they have abolished from their flesh.

text.title: for [with] your evil, then you rejoice:

pasuk.text: When you commit a transgression, you rejoice.

text.title: to the sound of a great tumult:

pasuk.text: Heb. המולה, an expression of the tumult of a large multitude that will come upon them.

text.title: And the Lord let me know:

pasuk.text: So said the prophet, The Holy One, blessed be He, let me know their retribution.

text.title: And I was like a lamb [and] a bull:

pasuk.text: that will be brought to the slaughter.
Since I let them know of the evil, they plan to kill me.

Heb. אלוף ככבש. Dunash and Judah son of Kudish (Karish) interpreted it as a lamb and a bull, brought to the slaughter. And אלוף is like (Deut. 28:4) “the offspring of your cattle (אלפיך).” Although it was not stated ואלוף, we find similar cases, e.g., (Habukkuk 3:11) “The sun [and] the moon (ירח) stood on high” ; (Isaiah 38:14) “Like a crane [and] a swallow (עגור) so I chirp.” And Menahem interpreted אלוף ככבש, a large lamb (see Psalms 58:9, Rashi ad loc.), and Jonathan supports him, since he renders like a choice lamb.

text.title: Let us destroy his food with wood:

pasuk.text: Let us put poison into his food.

text.title: Let me see Your vengeance against them:

pasuk.text: He cursed the people of Anathoth.
Heb. אל-אנשי ענתות, like ענתות על-אנשי, upon the men of Anathoth.

text.title: You are right, O Lord, when I contend with You:

pasuk.text: When I debate with You, I know that you will be right in Your words, but I wish to argue with You so that You will let me know Your way.

text.title: Why has the way of the wicked prospered?:

pasuk.text: That You have given greatness to Nebuchadnezzar the wicked, and you have made him succeed in destroying Your house? Another explanation is that he was crying and complaining about the men of Anathoth.
Heb. שלו, an expression of שלוה, peace.

text.title: But You, O Lord, have known me:

pasuk.text: Also, concerning the men of Anathoth You have aided me, for You have known me.

text.title: Draw them out like sheep to the slaughter:

pasuk.text: Draw them out of life to death (detache les in French, separate them, cut them off). Comp. (Joshua 8:6) “until we have drawn (התיקנו) them from the city.”
Heb. הקדישם, prepare them.

text.title: How long will the land mourn and the grass of all the field dry out?:

pasuk.text: Up to here are the prophet’s words, and the Holy Spirit replies to him, “Because of the evil of its inhabitants, beasts and fowl are ended.”
Be waste.
(finira in French, will terminate).
i.e., the inhabitants of this land have said.
It is not revealed to Him what will be at our end.

text.title: For if you have run with foot men and they wearied you:

pasuk.text: Your kin, the priests like you and the men of your city come to kill you.
Heb. רגלים (pieton in O.F), pedestrian.

text.title: how will you compete with horses:

pasuk.text: To run with the horses. That is to say, If even your brethren the priests come to kill you, surely the princes of Judah will rise up against you to kill you. This is the reason for My anger against them, and this is the reason for the success of the enemy. And so did Jonathan render: This is the reply, etc. And, according to the Midrash of our Rabbis (Sanhedrin 96a): If you are amazed about the reward for the three steps that Nebuchadnezzar ran in My honor in the days of Merodach-baladan, why I gave him so much greatness, how much more will you be amazed when you see the payment of reward that I will pay the righteous who ran before Me like horses!
(aastir in O.F.).

text.title: and in the peaceful land that you trust:

pasuk.text: there they wearied you.

text.title: how will you do in the heights:

pasuk.text: The princes of Judah. The pride of the Jordan is symbolic since it is a place of lions and tigers, and Jonathan taught us this in many places. And here he paraphrased. And how do you expect to do against the wild beasts that are on the height of the Jordan?“And behold, as a lion ascends from the height of the Jordan,” Jonathan renders in two places (infra 49:19, 50:44): like a lion that ascends from the height of the Jordan.

text.title: have called a gang after you:

pasuk.text: Heb. מלא, a group of men.
My treasured people.

text.title: she raised her voice against Me:

pasuk.text: The cry of her violent deeds has ascended before Me.

text.title: Is… a speckled bird of prey?:

pasuk.text: The ‘heh’ is that of the interrogative. Therefore, it is vowelized with a ‘pattah.’ Are they like a speckled bird of prey, stained with blood, around which other birds gather? Another explanation:

text.title: Is… a speckled bird of prey:

pasuk.text: One bird is speckled, and all the birds gather around it to eat it because they hate it.

text.title: Are there birds of prey around her?:

pasuk.text: Are these armies fowl of the heavens, the swift troops that are around her?
The commanders of the troops of Nebuchadnezzar’s army, as it is stated above (6:3): “Shepherds and their flocks shall come to her.”
Heb. בססו, an expression of trampling. Cf. (Zech. 10:5) “And they shall be like mighty men trampling (בוסים) the mire of the streets.”
Heb. חלקתי, (campagne in French), countryside.

text.title: the wasted one mourns before Me:

pasuk.text: Heb. עלי, lit. on Me.

text.title: They sowed wheat, but they reaped thorns:

pasuk.text: They prayed, but their prayer was not accepted. Why? Because they did not plow for themselves a furrow of repentance and good deeds. Therefore, they sowed seeds resulting in thorns. A book in which זרעו is vowelized with a ‘chirik’ under the ‘zayin,’ is erroneous.
Heb. נחלו, an expression of illness. They have become ill with their pain and their cry before Me, but they did not avail.
Of your deeds.
Egypt, Ammon and Moab, Tyre and Sidon, who were neighbors of Eretz Israel and were inflicting harm upon them.

text.title: I will return and have pity on them:

pasuk.text: They all suffered close to the destruction of the Temple, and concerning each one it is stated in this Book, “I will return the exile of…”
If they proselytize.
an expression of building.
(pourceint in O.F.).

text.title: and do not put it in water:

pasuk.text: to wash it when it will be soaked with sweat, in order that it hasten to decay.

text.title: it was of no use for anything:

pasuk.text: It was not fit for anything.

text.title: and it shall be like this girdle:

pasuk.text: Their pride shall be like this rotten girdle.
Heb. נבל. This is an earthenware vessel, and it is used to hold wine.

text.title: And I will dash them one against the other:

pasuk.text: I will dash one against the other until they break into small pieces. Cf (Psalms 2:9) “Like a potter’s vessel shall you shatter them (תנפצם)” (ibid. 137:9).“And dash ונפץ your babes”; and so is every expression of נפוץ in Scripture.

text.title: and the fathers and the sons:

pasuk.text: I will dash one against the other.
Heb. יתנגפו (achopper in French), to stumble.
Heb. נשף, the dark mountains when they go into exile.

text.title: and making it into a thick cloud:

pasuk.text: Heb. ושית, like ולשית, and to make the light into a thick cloud.
Because of your greatness which will be curtailed. Another explanation: Because of the pride of the kingdom of Heaven that will be given over to the idols of Babylon.

text.title: to the king and to the queen mother:

pasuk.text: Jehoiachin and his mother.
Heb. מראשתיכם (vostremijevec in O.F.), your ascent, as it is stated: (II Kings 24: 12) “And Jehoiachin… came out to him (sic), he and his mother and his servants,” and he led all of them in exile.

text.title: The cities of the South are shut up:

pasuk.text: before those coming upon them from the north [i.e.,] the cities of Eretz Israel are shut up because of fear of Nebuchadnezzar.

Jehoiachin will not wage war, but he will come out peacefully, and he will exile them. Another interpretation. שלומים (gueredon in O.F.), reprisal. That is to say: she was exiled as the recompense for their iniquity. And Jonathan rendered in this manner: the recompense of their sins was received.
those coming upon you from the North.

text.title: Where is the flock that was given you:

pasuk.text: After they are exiled, this will be said to Jerusalem.

text.title: What will you say when He visits:

pasuk.text: i.e., when the Holy One, blessed be He, visits upon you?

text.title: when you accustomed them to be princes at your head:

pasuk.text: You sent emissaries to the Chaldees to bring their idols from there to worship them, as it is written in Ezekiel (23 16): “And she lusted for them to the sight of her eyes, and she sent emissaries to them, to the Chaldees.” Another explanation of “you accustomed them to be princes over you” : Hezekiah who showed the emissaries of Merodach-baladan his entire treasure house (Isaiah 39:2, II Kings 20:13).
The skirts of the garments (tes ourlets in French), your hems. When a woman is stripped in a humiliating way, they turn her chemise upside down.
Your ways are cut off. נחמסו is like (Lam. 2:6) “And He cut off (ויחמֹס) like a garden His dwelling.”
(traces in O.F.) Travelers have stopped.
Heb. כושי, the name of a black man, who is called Maure in French, a Moor.
leopard in French.
The leopard is spotted, and they are the spots (taches in French), and it is impossible for them to change.
Heb. הרע, like להרע, to do evil.
The portion of your measures, a measure for a measure.
I have uncovered the hems of your garments upon your face.
like the neighing of adulterous horses.
will you ever become purified?

that He would bring famine upon them, and Menahem (Machbereth p. 47) classified it as an expression of fortification (מִבְצָר) like (Isaiah 25:12) “And the fortress of (וּמִבְצַר) the strength of your walls.”
Heb. וּשְעָרֶיהָ, lit., her gates.
Heb. צִוְחַת, the cry of Jerusalem. Comp. (Isaiah 42:11)"from the mountain peaks they shall shout (יִצְוָחוּ).
Pits in which the water is usually gathered.
for no rain has fallen.
an expression of covering.
bubirs [?] in O.F.
her offspring, to hunt for pastureland for herself.
rivulets of water (riveyres in O. F.).
Heb. עָנוּ.

Do what You will do with us for the sake of the great name that has spread about You that You rule over all and that we are Your people and the flock of Your pasture, and it is not fitting that You give Your victorious name to the idols. And the Midrash Aggadah explains: for the sake of Your name that is inherent in our name.
מִקְוֵה
(d’cru in O.F.) diminished, waned, who withdraws his hand from the battle, and some say (recroyant in O.F.), tiring out, resigned.

text.title: and Your name is called upon us:

pasuk.text: Therefore, by doing this, it is no longer honor for you.
Its explanation is like תַעַזְבֵנוּ, forsake us.

text.title: So have they loved to wander:

pasuk.text: So, just as I have decreed upon them exile (to Egypt and Babylon - Warsaw edition), they loved it there to go into exile to worship distant idols.
an expression of אַל, not, a thing which is not.
an expression of illness (חֹלִי).
They have gone around to seek rescue.

text.title: to a land [which] they had not known:

pasuk.text: To another land about which they did not know until then.

text.title: or has Your soul despised Zion:

pasuk.text: with the intention of never returning, for, if You have in mind to return, why have You smitten us without a cure?
that you are called merciful.
The Temple. And according to Midrash Aggadah, Israel who is engraved on the throne of Your glory.

by itself, except by Your command? This is the interrogative form. In every double question, the first question is preceded by a ‘heh’ and the second one with אִם, like (Num. 13:19) “Are they in open cities (הַבְּמַחֲנִים) or in fortresses (אִם בְּמִבְצָרִים) ?” (Ibid. 13:19) “It is good (הֲטוֹבָה) or bad (אִם רָעָה) ?” (verse 19) “Have You indeed rejected (הֲמָאֹס) Judah, or has Your soul despised (אִםגָּעֲלָה) Zion?” Here, too, “are there among the vanities of the nations those who give rain? Does the heaven…?”

Both were needed to beg mercy for Israel, but first they induced them to repent, and afterwards they prayed on their behalf, but they had no idea of turning away My wrath until they had induced them to repent. Moses said (Exodus 32:27), “Let each man put his sword…” (v. 20) “and he scattered it on the surface of the water, etc.” And afterwards (v. 30), “I will ascend to the Lord, perhaps I will atone.” Samuel in Mizpah (I Samuel 7:4, 5) “And the children of Israel removed the Baalim,” and afterwards, “‘Gather all Israel to Mizpah, and I shall pray to the Lord on your behalf (sic).’” But you cannot bring them back to Me, therefore do not pray for them.
Heb. נַפֹשִי lit., My soul.

text.title: Such as are for death, to death:

pasuk.text: Each calamity mentioned later in this verse is harsher than the one preceding it. The sword is harsher than death. Death by the sword is defacing, whereas death in bed is not defacing. And so he says (Psalms 116:15): “Precious in the eyes of the Lord is the death of His Saints.” Famine is harsher than the sword, for this one is agonizing whereas the other is not agonizing. And so Scripture states (Lam. 4:9): “Better are those who die from the sword than those who die from famine.” Captivity - all sorts of death are in it.
an expression of appointment and designation.
to drag. Cf. (infra. 49:20) “If the young of the sheep do not drag them (יִסְחָבוּם).”
from the same root as (Esther 5:9), “And he neither rose nor quaked (זָע).” Similarly, גַּאֲוָה pride, from the root (Isa. 16: 6) “Have become very proud (גֵּא).”

text.title: to all the kingdoms of the earth:

pasuk.text: Anyone who hears the evil that has befallen you will shudder.
Heb. יָנוּד.
to you, to turn aside from his road to you, to ask of your welfare?
Many times I planned to destroy but repented of the evil. Now I am weary of repenting. הִנָחֵם (Dporpnser in O.F.)
A sieve called (van in French), like one who winnows barley, so that they should not all be exiled to one place.
His widows are more to Me.
Upon Jerusalem, which is a city and a mother in Israel.
Everything will be exposed before him, all their hidden treasures.

text.title: I have cast upon her suddenly a city:

pasuk.text: I caused the troops of a city and many terrors to rest upon her. Some interpret עִיר as ‘an enemy.’ Cf. (I Sam. 28:16), “And has become [the supporter of] your adversary (עָרֶ) ” (see also Dan. 4:16).
Samaria and the nation of the Ten Tribes, from whom rose seven dynasties of wicked kings, has already been cut off and exiled.

These are Judah and part of Benjamin, who remained in Israel. I shall deliver them to the sword. These are the seven dynasties: Jeroboam son of Nebat and his dynasty, Baasha and his dynasty, Omri and his dynasty, Jehu and his dynasty, Menahem and his dynasty, Pekah and his dynasty, Hoshea and his dynasty.
an expression of ‘her soul grieves.’ We translate (Deut. 28:65) “And grieving of the soul (וְדַאֲבוֹן נֶפֹש)” as וּמַפְּחַן נְפֹש.

Before its time, they hastened to fall. In this manner it is expounded in Tractate Gittin. [See Gittin 88a]. And in the Midrash of Rabbi Tanhuma (Tanhuma Buber, Vayetze p. 153) it is expounded as referring to Jerusalem, and he counts seven wicked men: Jehoram, Jehoash, Ahaz, Manasseh, Amon, Jehoiakim, and Zedekiah. But there are yet to count Rehoboam, Abijah, Amaziah, and Ahaziah.
an expression of shame.

text.title: Woe is to me, my mother:

pasuk.text: Jeremiah was complaining about himself, that his townsmen hated him because of his castigations.
a man of quarrel, Cf. (Gen. 6:3) “Let My spirit not contend (יָדוֹן).”
Cf. (Exodus 22:24) “You shall not be to him as a creditor (כְּנֹשֶה).”
I do not quarrel with them concerning matters of money that I claim from them, neither have they made any claim on me, yet all the people curse me.

I leave you over, an expression of a remnant. In this manner, Menahem (Machbereth p. 181) interpreted it, but Dunash (Teshuvoth Dunash p. 36) interpreted it as an expression of release. And שֵרִיתִי is like (Dan. 5:12) “And untying (וּמֹשָרֵא) knots,” and the interpretation of שֵרִיתִי is so, as it is stated (below 40:4): “Behold I have released you from the chains that are on your hand.” That is to say, on that day that the Lord fulfilled His word, it was said to him, “And now, behold I have released you today from the chains that are on your hand, if it pleases you to come with me to Babylon.” And also, Israel begged him to pray for them, as it was said to him (below 42: 4): “Pray on our behalf to the Lord our Cod, for we remain few from many.”
lit., if not, an expression of an oath.

text.title: I will cause [them] to beg you in time of evil:

pasuk.text: with the enemy. When evil befalls them, they will beg you to supplicate God for mercy upon them, for example, Zedekiah said to him, (below 21:2) “Beseech God now on our behalf, etc.” Another explanation. Nebuzaradan will beg you (below 40:4), “If it pleases you to come with me to Babylon.”

text.title: Will iron break iron from the north:

pasuk.text: I say that iron that comes from the north is harder than other iron, and this is its interpretation: They were compared to iron (above 6:28), “Going tale bearing like copper and iron.” And concerning Jeremiah it is stated (above 1:18): “I have made you… into an iron pillar and into copper walls,” and his is stronger than theirs, for Nebuchadnezzar will come upon them according to his words.

Will their iron break yours? Another explanation: Will Pharaoh who comes in your aid, who is as hard as iron, break Nebuchadnezzar, who is iron that comes from the north and copper? Targum Jonathan is inclined toward this direction.
An expression of money.
He is addressing Israel.
And because of all your sins, this will befall you.
For you erected idols in all of them.

text.title: Take me not to Your long suffering:

pasuk.text: Jonathan renders. Do not grant a reprieve for my humiliation. Do not take my cause to leave it for Your long suffering, but hasten and avenge me.
like סָבַלְתִּי bore.
for You.

text.title: Your words were found and I ate them:

pasuk.text: eagerly at the beginning, and they were a joy for me, for I thought that now they would listen to me.
Because of the prophecy that came to me from You.
alone and bewildered by mourning, for You filled me with a prophecy of fury concerning the destruction of Your House.
sick. Comp. (II Sam. 12:15) “And he became mortally ill (וַיֵּאָנֹש).” mentioned concerning Bath-sheba’s son.
Heb. הָיו ֹתִהְיֶה.
Like a man whose trust has been cut off from him, for you allow me to suffer at their hands. אַכְזָב is a spring that stops (faylayne in O.F:), failing.
to rely upon it.
Because I suffer from these troubles.
to me.
You, Israel, through me, and I will return you to Him, He said to Me, “You will stand before Me.”

text.title: and if you take precious out of the vile:

pasuk.text: If you take a pious man from a wicked man, i.e., if you bring him to repentance.

text.title: You shall be as my mouth:

pasuk.text: For I make a decree and you annul it.

text.title: Let them return to you, but you shall not return to them:

pasuk.text: Let them return to your word, but you shall not return to stray after them.
feasting. In Sifrei, in the section dealing with Beth-peor (Balak), I saw. They returned to make feasts (מַרְזֵיחִין) for them, but our Rabbis explained מַרְזֵחַ as ‘a mourner.’
you shall lament.

text.title: for I have gathered in My peace, etc.:

pasuk.text: When their father Abraham performed charity and justice, I gave his children loving-kindness and mercy, as in Deut. 7:12: “And the Lord your God shall keep for you the covenant and the loving- kindness, etc.” Also (Deut. 13:18), “And He shall give you mercy.” They turned “justice into wormwood, and cast righteousness to the ground” (Amos 5:7). I, too, have returned and gathered in to Me My loving-kindness and My mercies.
(ote in O.F.), taken off. Comp. (Gen. 30:23) “God has gathered (אסף) in my disgrace.”

text.title: And large and small shall die:

pasuk.text: And since everyone will die, why should you lament?

text.title: and they shall not cut their flesh nor shall they tear their hair for them:

pasuk.text: It is the custom of mourners to cut and tear their flesh and to tear their hair our of their head. In any case, it is forbidden for Jews, but he mentions it here only as an example of mourning.

text.title: And they shall not break [bread] for them:

pasuk.text: an expression of breaking. Comp. (Dan. 5:25) “Mene Mene Tekel Upharsin, (divided).” This alludes to the practice of giving a meal to the mourners in the city square and they break for them the bread upon reciting the blessing of ‘hamotzi.’ (I Sam. 9:13) “For he will bless the sacrifices,” Jonathan renders: He will break (פָרִיס) bread.

text.title: neither will they give them to drink etc:

pasuk.text: This is the reason for what I said, “Neither go to lament.”

text.title: And to a house of feasting:

pasuk.text: that I said to you above, “You shall not go,” this is the reason: Behold, I will cut off from this place, etc.

text.title: and you will serve there other gods:

pasuk.text: Jonathan paraphrases: And you will serve there nations that worship idols day and night.
An expression of an oath. Although you betrayed Me, I have an oath that I will redeem you.

text.title: and it shall no longer be said:

pasuk.text: Our Rabbis expounded: Not that the departure from Egypt shall be uprooted from its place, but the final redemption will be the most important and the departure from Egypt secondary to it.

Just as the fisher takes - it i.e., - the fish from its habitat, so will these capture them within the city, and just as the manner of a fish, that when he is caught he dies, so will I bring killers upon them, and afterwards I will send hunters for the survivors and for those who flee from the sword to the mountains and the hills, and they will hunt them to exile them in captivity.
Because they repeated their iniquity to do the iniquities of their fathers. And Jonathan renders in this manner: And I will recompense the second ones like the first ones double.

(mon vantement in French), my boast. And Menahem (Machbereth p. 123) classified it as an expression of a wonder. Cf. (Psalms 60:6) “You have given those who fear You a wonder to be wondrous (נֵס לְהִתְנוֹסֵס).”
Eventually, the heathens will come to you and worship You of one accord, and they will say, “How did they make gods for themselves, and they are no gods?”
Like מִקְצֵה, from the end of.
an expression of an inheritance.
an expression of use (תּוֹעֶלֶת).

text.title: that My name is the Lord:

pasuk.text: As its apparent meaning, a ruler and a sovereign to fulfill My decree.

This is an allegory. That is to say that it is deeply engraved, and cannot be erased. And the Midrash Aggadah explains: with a pen of iron, with a diamond point, preserved by Jeremiah, called ‘an iron wall,’ and by Ezekiel, to whom it was said (3:9): “As a diamond, harder than flint have I made your forehead.”
Engraved like one who plows deeply.

text.title: on the tablet of their heart:

pasuk.text: that they do not forget their idolatry.

text.title: As they remember their children, [so do they remember] their altars:

pasuk.text: Like the remembrance of their children, so was the remembrance of their altars to them, like a man who longs for his son.
which are by the green trees.
like אֵצֶּל, by. And Jonathan renders in this manner. under every green tree.

text.title: You, who sit upon the mountain in the field:
