pasuk.text: Jerusalem that is situated on the mountain of the plain. All around the city is a fielded plain. The structure of הֲרָרִי is like עֲרָבִי, called so because he dwells in the plain (עֲרָבָה) (montanyers in O.F), mountain dwellers (other versions: a mountain dweller).
like מָמוֹנְ, your money.

text.title: Your high places are made for sin:

pasuk.text: Your high places are made in sin for the purpose of idolatry within all your borders.
Perforce you will release your land for the time that it did not rest on your Sabbaths, which I said to you (Lev. 25:2), “And the land shall rest a Sabbath for the Lord.”

I will avenge Myself of you because of your heritage that I gave you, that you did not perform My will to release it. Another explanation: even of you, from your heritage; I will avenge Myself of you from your heritage, that I will exile you from it.

text.title: for you have kindled fire in My nostrils:

pasuk.text: Heb. קְדַכְתֶּם.
In his plowing and his harvest, saying, “I will sow during the seventh year and I will eat.”
Like ‘his help,’ and so did Jonathan render: his trust.

text.title: and whose heart turns away from the Lord:

pasuk.text: Who promised him (Lev. 25:21), “And I will command My blessing to you.” This is what I heard.

like a lonely tree, an expression of (Gen. 15:2) “Childless (עֲרִירִי) ,” and some say (degat in O.F) laid waste, and Menahem (Machbereth Menahem p. 137) explained: The name of a tree of the forest trees, and its name is ar’ar, and this is the explanation of (infra 48. 6) “Like an ‘aroer’ in the desert,” one of the trees of the forest.
an expression of a plain.
aridness. Comp. (Job 30:30) “Became dry (חָרָה) from heat.”
Land that is salty and will not be settled.
The tree will not see when heat comes.
an expression of hunger, (famine in French). Another interpretation: בַּצֹרֶת is an expression of fortification (מִבְצָר) , and in this manner, Menahem (Machbereth Menahem p. 47) classified it.
will not be afraid.
Full of pretext and deceit of all evil.
an expression of sickness, and this is its sickness.
He thinks, “Who recognizes it?” I, the Lord, search it.
(Coucou glousse in French).

This cuckoo draws after it chicks that it did not lay. דָגָר - This is the chirping which the bird chirps with its voice to draw the chicks after it, but those whom the cuckoo called will not follow it when they grow up for they are not of its kind. So is one who gathers riches but not by right.
He is called wicked.

Since he wishes to state: All that forsake You shall be shamed, he commences with the praise of the Omnipresent, and says before Him, “You, Whose Throne of Glory is exalted from the beginning of the Creation of the world and is directed opposite our Sanctuary.”

text.title: The Lord Who is the source of the hopes of Israel:

pasuk.text: sits upon it. Therefore, all that forsake You shall be shamed.

text.title: and they that turn away from me shall be marked on the earth:

pasuk.text: Those who turn away from my words, who do not hearken to my message, will be marked out in the nether graves of the earth.
I praise myself and boast with You, saying that You are my Savior (vantance in O.F.), boast.

text.title: "Where is the word of the Lord?:

pasuk.text: The retribution which you prophesy.
I did not hasten to urge You to bring them because I am a good shepherd, who goes after You to beg mercy for them.

The illness of their retribution I did not desire. Jonathan renders: And I did not hamper Your word from prophesying concerning them to return them to fear You. According to the Targum, אַצְתִּי is an expression of hampering. That is to say, I did not hesitate from telling them Your message and to return them to you if they would hearken to me.

text.title: What came out of my lips was before Your face:

pasuk.text: to return Your wrath from them.

text.title: Let it not be to me for a ruin:

pasuk.text: Let not Your mission be to me for a ruin.
i.e., the men of Anathoth alone.
i.e., your forefathers did not hearken to what I commanded them.
like וְלָבֹא.
Jonathan renders: on the wheel. (Formes in French.)

text.title: that he was making of clay:

pasuk.text: That he was making of the clay was spoiled in the potter’s hand while it was still wet, and this is an inverted verse.

text.title: of its evil for which I spoke concerning it:

pasuk.text: Of its sins for which I spoke concerning it.
(depayser [?] in French).
And I will think another thought.

text.title: But they shall say, We despair:

pasuk.text: I know that they will say to you regarding your words that they do not heed them.
Heb. שַעֲרֻרִת.

text.title: Shall one abandon from rocks of the field the snow of Lebanon:

pasuk.text: Shall a man who needs to drink abandon water that flows from the rock in the fields that comes from the snow of the Lebanon, which is clean?

text.title: Shall strange cold… water be abandoned?:

pasuk.text: Or shall flowing spring water, which was strange to all people until now, and it is cold, be abandoned? זָרִים means flowing, and this proves it (2 Kings 19: 24): “I dug and drank strange water (זָרִים).” Menahem, however, classified with (Isaiah 1:6) “they have not been sprinkled (זֹרוּ), neither have they been bandaged,” an expression of curative water, and he gave a reason for his statement, and he said that if he wished to speak with an expression of זֶרֶם, a stream, he would double the ‘mem,’ and he would add ‘yud’ ‘mem,’ and he would say זְרוּמִים because of the plural number of מַיִם water, and because they are streams (זְרָמִים).
like שָדֶה, a field
(froids in French).
(courants in French). And we can also interpret it: “Shall it be abandoned to be strange rejected water, the water that is cold running water?”
צרים According to the first interpretation, it is an expression of a stream [זֶרֶם]. According to the second interpretation, it is an expression of strangeness, i.e., rejected water.)
so have My people done, that they have forgotten Me and burnt incense to vanity.
The proper paths they said that they are a stumbling block, in order to go…

text.title: [on] a way that is not trodden down:

pasuk.text: Heb. סְלוּלָה.
One who passes by ruins that he already saw with good buildings is accustomed to whistle.
will wonder.

text.title: upon their back and not their face:

pasuk.text: when they flee from before the enemy, I will look upon them and I will not save them.
but I will not save them.
Jeremiah was complaining about the men of Anathoth and saying that they say this.
For it is incumbent upon the priests to teach the Torah, as it is stated (Deut. 33:10): “They shall teach Your ordinances to Jacob.”
I. e., words of prophecy.

text.title: Come, let us strike him with the tongue:

pasuk.text: Let us testify falsely against him.
(Bring them down by the sword,) an expression of (Lam. 3:49) “My eye runs (נִגְרָה) ” ; (Micah 1:4) “Like water that runs (מֻגָרִים).”
by troops.
i.e., the husbands of the widows shall be slain by the angel of death.

text.title: for they dug a pit to seize me:

pasuk.text: that they suspected him of intimacy with a married woman, as it is stated (Prov. 23:27): “For a harlot is a deep pit (ֹשוּחָה).”
let it not be erased. And because it is a feminine gender, he placed a ‘yud’ therein. This too is superfluous, as the ‘yud’ of (Ezekiel 16:17) “And you played the harlot (וַתִּזְנִי) with them.”
Heb. בַּקְבֻּק.
That is to say, of a potter, which is of earthenware.

text.title: and some of the elders of the people:

pasuk.text: take along with you.“And of the elders of the people” refers back to ‘Go,’ and some of the elders of the people with you.
The Dung Gate, where broken pottery is cast, and Jonathan rendered in this manner תְרַע קִלְקַלְתָּא.
(tinter in French), an expression similar to “cymbals” (מְצִלְתַּיִם) (Neh. 12:27), “with loud sounding cymbals (בְּצִלְצְלֵי ֹשָמַע) ” (Psalms 150:5).
They made it strange before Me.
and I will empty, an expression similar to (Nahum 2:11), “She is empty and void וּמְבוּקָה) (בּוּקָה,” and because of the jug (בַּקְבֻּק) about which he is speaking, he adopted this expression.
An expression of pain, like צוקה.
This refers to the people, but the city I will make like the Topheth and purify it in the future.]
All of it will be full of the slain just as the Topheth, where they slay the children for Molech.

text.title: and placed him in the prison:

pasuk.text: the name of a place of a prison, and Jonathan rendered: לכיפתא (arvolud in O.F.), a vault.
Terror.

text.title: Not Passhur did the Lord call your name, etc.:

pasuk.text: Your name was not called Pashhur except for this matter, that is to say: פֹשַח ֹשָחוֹר, cut off and black like “a tree that was cut off (נִפֹשַח)” (Shevi’ith 4:6, Orlah 1:5). Also (Lam. 3:11), “And He cut me off (וַיִפֹשְחֵנִי).” And so he said to him, Not Pashhur did He call your name, for the expression of Pashhur means a great man and the son of nobles, Pashhur. ‘Pash’ denotes expansion and ‘hur’ nobility. But for this reason your name was called Pashhur, Pashah shahor. ‘Pashah’ means ‘cut off,’ and ‘shahor’ means ‘black.’ Another explanation. ‘Pashah sehor.’ Many will be around you to slay you. Now according to this explanation, מָגוֹר is an expression of gathering, like (Ezekiel 21: 17) “Gathered (מְגוּרֵי) to the sword.”
money.
to go on your mission.
You made Your strong hand heavy upon me to go against my will.
And You were victorious.
All the people mock me.
Every time I speak to them, I must cry out and raise my voice, and I do not proclaim good for them but prophecies of violence and spoil.

text.title: for the word of the Lord has been… for me:

pasuk.text: Therefore, they spoke to me with scorn, for they scorn me.
for speech. Comp. (Ezekiel 22:4) “and mockery (וְקַלָּסָה).”

text.title: Should I say: I will not mention Him:

pasuk.text: If my heart said to me not to go on Your mission anymore.

text.title: it would be in my heart:

pasuk.text: i.e., the prophecy.
And against my will I must go.
And as if the fire were confined in my bones.
To endure the fire.
I said that I would not mention Him because I heard the speech of many, those who whisper about me.
an expression of gathering, and so did Jonathan render it.
false testimony against him.

text.title: and let us tell about him:

pasuk.text: and let us testify against him. And Menahem (Machbereth p. 53) explained ונגידֶנוּ like (Deut. 14:1) “You shall not cut yourselves (לא תתגודדוּ).” He also joined (Job 17:5) “For the sake of flattering, he destroys (יגיד) his friends.” This is an expression of destruction. Comp. (Dan. 4:11) “Cut down (גֹדוּ) the trees.” But Dunash (Teshuvoth p. 54) interpreted it as an actual expression of telling, and this is its interpretation: “Tell false things about him and we will tell about him to the king.” And we have like נַגִידֶנוּ, we will tell about him, many words in the Scriptures that cannot be interpreted unless they are divided into two words or three. Comp. (Gen. 37:4) “And they could not speak with him (דַבְּרוֹ) peacefully.” Also (supra 10:20), “My children have left me (יצאני).”
Heb. צַלְעֵי Perhaps he will be enticed.

text.title: to listen to us and to stray after us.:

pasuk.text: and we will prevail against him to bring him to commit idolatry.
They did not succeed with their plan.

text.title: Cursed be the day in which I was begotten:

pasuk.text: (engendrer or engenrer in O.F.). That is the time of conception, and through compulsion Hilkiah his father performed the marriage act by day, for he was fleeing from before Manasseh, who was slaying the prophets, and he performed the marriage act and fled.
The ‘mem’ is punctuated with a ‘dagesh,’ which is an expression of making others glad, for he made his father glad with his news.
Namely Sodom and Gemorrah.
Since He decreed destruction upon them, he did not think another thought to rescind His decree.

text.title: That he did not put me to death:

pasuk.text: I.e., that the angel of death did not put me to death from the womb, and this is one of the verses with brief language.
a pregnancy of eternity.
The destruction of the Temple.

text.title: Behold I turn back the weapons of war:

pasuk.text: There are some among you who know how to adjure the heavenly princes in charge of retribution, that each one save them from the evil he is in charge of, and you rely on that. Behold, I will transfer one’s authority to another one, and you will not know whom to adjure.

i.e., the weapons of war, into this city, that I will destroy you with pestilence through the angel of death, who is one of the heavenly princes. And in this manner it is explained in the chapter (v. 6): “with a great pestilence they shall die.”

text.title: and he will have his life as a prey:

pasuk.text: As a man who plunders booty, and he seizes and goes away, so will his life be plundered from death by the slayers.
as the Targum, רוּגְזִי My anger.

text.title: from the hand of the robber:

pasuk.text: Its accent is below for it is not a noun but a noun denoting the robber who robs others.
that no one of you will escape as a survivor.
Jerusalem is in the midst of a valley. Another explanation. That the Holy One, blessed be He, devised a deep plot against you to destroy you.
Mountain, entirely surrounded by plain.
who will encamp upon us. Comp. (II Kings 6:9) “For there the Arameans are encamped (נְחִתִּים).”
This means taunting with words.

text.title: You are [as] Gilead to Me, etc.:

pasuk.text: Even if you are as dear to Me as the Temple, which is high on the mountain peaks, I swear that I will make you a desert.
The Temple from which balm and healing emanate to the whole world.
and I will prepare.

text.title: and they will cut your choice cedars:

pasuk.text: Since he compares him to the Lebanon, this expression is appropriate.
Namely, for Jehoiakim, who will die before the gate, when they drag him into exile.

For Jehoiachin and for Zedekiah. Deduce from here that Jehoiakim’s death, concerning which it is stated (infra 36: 30): “And his carcass shall be cast to the heat by day and to the cold at night,” is preferable to the life of Jehoiachin, about whom it is stated (52:34): “And his meals, regular meals, etc.”

That is Zedekiah, and that is what he was called in I Chron. (3:14): “the fourth Shallum.” And he called him the Fourth, meaning the fourth to assume the kingship of Josiah’s sons, for first Jehoaha, reigned, then Jehoiakim, and after him Jehoiachin, and after him Zedekiah.
Even though he hadn’t left yet, he prophesied as if he had already left.

text.title: Woe to him who builds his house:

pasuk.text: He is saying this about Jehoiakim, who was a wicked man, and the end of the section proves this: “Therefore, so said the Lord about Jehoiakim.”
a large house. Cf. (Num. 13: 32) “Men of great stature (אַנֹשֵי מִדּוֹת) ,” who have what to measure.

text.title: and he cuts out… for himself:

pasuk.text: And he widens for himself (Some emend: And he opens for himself) Comp. (supra 4:30) “that you enlarge (וַתִּקְרְעִי) … with paint.” Also (Isaiah 63:19), “Had You rent (קָרַעְתְּ) the heavens, had You descended.” They are all an expression of opening.
He covers the roof with cedars.

painted with dyes, so does Jonathan render. בּשָּׁשַּׁר is a color of a type used for painting. Another explanation: וּמָשּׁוֹח ַבִּשָּׁשַּׁר is like a cord used for measuring (חוּט הַמִּשְּׁחָה) ([a] lignant en sinople in O.F.), drawing green lines, delineate with a green color.
Will you live long that you contend to make your rule oppressive to let all know that you are a king?
Josiah, who demeaned himself with humility, did he not eat and drink and enjoy pleasure all the days of his life?
to steal money.

the crushing of the poor, and עֹשֶק, oppression proves it, for ‘oppressed’ and ‘crushed’ are always juxtaposed in the language of the Scriptures. Cf. (I Sam. 12:3) “Whom did I oppress or whom did I crush?”
Woe for his glory.
As they drag the carcass of a donkey, so will they drag his carcass. The word יֹשַגְּרוּן used by Targum Jonathan means, they will drag.
Go up to the Temple and cry.

text.title: and on Bashan give forth your voice:

pasuk.text: On Bashan which will be destroyed. And Jonathan paraphrased: And in the gates of the Temple Mount. And I do not know how to explain how the expression ‘Bashan’ fits to the gates of the Temple Mount, unless it is because of the doors which they make from the terebinths of Bashan, and that is the name of a place, or the expression, ‘Bashan’ denotes a place of a wide valley. So is the area of the Temple Mount an open area around the Temple.
And cry for Megizatha. They are place names.
when you lived in peace.
All your kings.

text.title: shall be broken by the wind:

pasuk.text: The east wind shall break them.
For you placed your nest in the towers of the cedar houses to build wide houses.

What grace have you found because of the height of your towers, in the eyes of your plunderers, when birth pangs come upon you. And Menahem interpreted נֵחַנְתְּ as an expression of camping, but Dunash interpreted it as an expression of grace.
Engraved and sealed in the flesh of My arm.

Cf. (supra 12:3) “Draw them out (התִקֵם) like sheep to the slaughter” (Jos. 8:6) “Until we have drawn (התִקֵינוּ) them.” And the ‘nun’ is superfluous. And, according to the Midrash Aggadah (Pesikta d’Rav Kahana, p. 163a): In the place to which he was removed (נִתַּק), there he was rectified (נִתְקַן) , for he repented in Babylon, and the Holy One, blessed be He, applied for absolution of the oath He had sworn, “Inscribe this man childless.” and Zerubbabel was born to him in Babylon, and it was said to him through the prophet (Haggai 2:23), “On that day… I will take you, Zerubbabel, and I will make you as a signet,” directed toward what He said to his father, “Though… be a signet on My right arm,… I will remove him (sic).”
an expression of throwing.
This is an expression of consolation, that their soul lifts itself to console itself and to say, “We will again return to our land.”
It is a rhetorical question. Is this man a broken and despised image, that he was cast away from My face like a vessel in which there is no use?

broken. Cf. (Psalms 2:8) “Like a potter’s vessel you shall shatter them (תְּנַפְּצֵם).” [Others annotated: הַעֶצֶב is like the idols (הָעֲצַבִּים).“We may swathe (מְעַצְּבִין) an infant” in Tractate Shabbath 22:6. That is to say, “Are you despised and broken in your eyes like a small infant who is being swathed (emmailloter in French)? This one is not worthy.”
thrown, an expression of throwing that has no restoration. Comp. (Psalms 37:24), “If he falls, he will not be cast off (יוּטָל).”
A land that is a land among lands, the most esteemed of all of them. Another explanation: Eretz Israel had three lands in it. Judea, Transjordania, and Galilee.

text.title: a man who will not prosper in his days:

pasuk.text: Inscribe him.
The kings of Judah.

text.title: and have not taken care of them:

pasuk.text: You were not careful to watch them.

text.title: nor shall [any of them] be missing:

pasuk.text: and they shall not be missing. (Cf. Num. 31:49) “And no one of us was missing (נפקד).”
Heb. והשכּיל.
The Lord will vindicate us during this one’s days.

text.title: Because of the prophets my heart is broken within me:

pasuk.text: Because of the words of the prophets who say, “You shall have peace,” my heart is broken.
sway like the wings of a bird who hovers over his nest, (trenblent in O.F.) tremble.
For I heard from Him this evil decree.
False oaths.
i.e., is destroyed.
(course in French,) their course, their running. But Jonathan renders it as an expression of desire.
Not according to the law.
Even these, from whom everyone learns.

text.title: even in My house have I found their evil:

pasuk.text: For they placed an image in the Temple.
Smooth ground upon which the foot slips and the person falls.

text.title: like slippery places in the dark:

pasuk.text: Stumbling upon stumbling. On slippery places in the light there is stumbling. In the dark without slippery places, there is stumbling.

text.title: And in the prophets of Samaria I saw unseemliness:

pasuk.text: before they were exiled.

text.title: And in the prophets of Jerusalem:

pasuk.text: I now see.
a shameful thing.
They say to the wicked, “You shall have peace.”
So that the evildoers would not return each one from his evil.

text.title: and everyone who follows the view of his heart:

pasuk.text: And to everyone who follows the view of his heart, etc.

text.title: For who stood in the council of the Lord:

pasuk.text: and will hear what is decreed by Him? He who hearkened to the word of His Torah and listened to His commandments, but not these wicked men. The first expression of ֹשְמִיעָה in the verse is actual hearing; the latter expression of ֹשְמִיעָה is an expression of acceptance.
A resting storm, a storm which seeks to rest, and it shall rest on the heads of the wicked.
an expression of thought.

text.title: And if they stood in My council, they should have let My people hear My word, etc.:

pasuk.text: They should have let My people hear My words and My Torah, rather than cause them to stray away from Me.

text.title: Am I a God from near:

pasuk.text: that I do not see but what is close to Me and have I no power to judge the lower creatures that are far from Me and do I not know of their deeds?

text.title: Can a man hide in secret places:

pasuk.text: This is a repetition of the question, ‘Am I a God from near,’ according to the manner of all double questions.
That they will prophesy falsely? Do these prophets who prophesy falsely have in their heart to execute their thoughts that they are thinking to cause My people to forget My name, etc.?
an expression of מִרְמָה, deceit.
Let him tell it as vain talk like other dreams, and let him not presume it as words of prophecy.

text.title: What has the straw to do with the wheat?:

pasuk.text: What has falsehood to do with truth?
like עִם-הַבָּר.

text.title: Is not My word so like fire?:

pasuk.text: They should not have erred to compare their dreams to say that they are prophecy, for the prophetic word, when it comes to a prophet, it comes into him with force like a burning fire, as the matter is stated (supra 20:9): “And it was in my heart like a burning fire,” and (Ezekiel 3:14): “And the hand of the Lord became strong upon me.”
(pic in French), a pick. And some say (marteau in French), a hammer.

text.title: those who steal My wards from one another:

pasuk.text: They have spies who spy upon the true prophets, who listen to their expression with which they prophesy and say false prophecies with that same expression, as Hananiah son of Azzur did. He heard Jeremiah prophesying in the upper marketplace, “Behold I break the bow of Elam,” and he prophesied in the lower marketplace, “I have broken the yoke of the king of Babylon” (28:2), as our Rabbis wrote in Sanhedrin 89a.
who teach their tongues to say their falsehoods with the expression, “Says the Lord,” like the true prophets, so that they should believe them.
an expression of wonder (estordisoun in O. F.).

text.title: “What is the burden of the Lord?”:

pasuk.text: This is an expression of derision, for his prophecy is a burden to them.

text.title: you shall say to them, “What burden? And I will forsake you, etc.”:

pasuk.text: They say to you (sic), “What is the burden?” You are the burden of the Holy One, blessed be He, and He says that He will forsake you and cast you off His arms from heaven to earth. So I heard.
Heb. וְעָזַבְתִּי.

text.title: For the burden shall be to the man of His word:

pasuk.text: Although you pervert the massa into a pejorative, the prophecy (משא) of the word of the Lord shall be to the man of His word, and to the man of His counsel He reveals it, but you pervert it to an expression of a burden. This interpretation I did not hear, but it is the main interpretation. But this is how I heard it, namely that the burden shall be a burden of retribution for the one who says it, who asks, “What is the burden?” Another interpretation: משא is an expression of prophecy, and the false prophet would ask the true prophet to tell him the word of the Holy One, blessed be He, in the language in which the expression came to him, and the expression did not explain the speech adequately. Therefore, the false prophet would pervert it to another meaning and would speak after the fashion of the true prophet in order that they should believe him. And so did Hananiah son of Azzur do. Therefore, he says, “Do not ask the prophecy of the Lord,” the language of the expression, but “What did He speak?” or “What did He reply?” The explanation of the words you shall ask the true prophet to tell you what the Holy One, blessed be He, says, and to what His words are inclined.

text.title: for the prophecy shall be for the man of His word:

pasuk.text: The unexplained expression the Holy One, blessed be He, said unexplained to the man of His counsel, who is not suspected of perverting it, but you ask it in order to pervert it, and you pervert the words of the Holy One, blessed be He, and that is what is stated above (v. 30): “those who steal My words from one another.” This too is a correct explanation.

text.title: So shall you say to the prophet:

pasuk.text: when you come to ask My words of the prophet.
an expression of “the sinew that was dislocated (גִיד הַנֹּשֶה) ” (Gen. 32:33), and an expression of “their might has failed (נֹשְתָה),” it jumps and moves from place to place.
Heb. דּוּדָאֵי.
Heb. מוּעדים.

text.title: the craftsmen and the sentries of the gates:

pasuk.text: Torah scholars who were exiled with Jeconiah, and I already explained in the Book of Kings (II 24:14) הֶחָרָש וְהַמַּסְגֵּר (les maitres, les portiers in French) the masters, the sentries of the gates. Another explanation: הֶחָרָש וְהַמַּסְגֵּר : הֶחָרָש is an expression of silence, וְהַמַּסְגֵּר is an expression of closing. That is to say, great sages in Torah, to the extent that when one of them would speak, everyone would remain silent. מַסְגֵּר means that when they would close the discussion, no one would reopen it.
that have ripened completely in the beginning of the ripening of the figs which are dear to all those who find them in their beginning.

text.title: so will I recognize the exile of, etc.:

pasuk.text: This is an inverted verse: So will I recognize for good the exile of Judah which I have already exiled, viz., Jeconiah and his exile.
an expression of uprooting.

text.title: for a horror [and] for evil for all the kingdoms of the earth:

pasuk.text: For they will hear the evil that came upon them and quake.
That everyone will repeat and discuss their retribution.

The year that their decree was sealed that they be exiled and that they drink the cup of wrath, as he says in this section (v. 15): “Take the cup, etc.,” and before the decree He commanded the prophet to reprove them, perhaps they would repent, and their decree would not be sealed.
Josiah reigned thirty-one years (II Kings 22:1). Subtract twelve years from them (Jer. 1:2). This leaves nineteen, and four of his son amount to twenty-three.
This is a present tense. I would arise early and speak constantly.
That is an indication of a circumcision feast, since they would grind and crush ingredients for healing the wound.
An indication of a feast. So we learned in Sanhedrin (32b).
concerning Babylon.
at its end.
Like ‘For… shall enslave them,’ i.e., shall enslave the people of Babylon.
Viz. Media and Persia.

text.title: cup of the wine of fury:

pasuk.text: The prophecy of retribution

text.title: and you shall give… to drink it:

pasuk.text: Prophesy to them that it will no longer be retracted for any repentance.
Jonathan renders: and they shall be confused.
an expression of madness, they shall be mad.
As they are today. Jeremiah wrote his Book after the destruction.
All the supports (סוּמְכְוָתָא) which are Pharaoh’s guarantee, and he leans upon them for aid.
Garantie in French.

text.title: and the kings of the isle:

pasuk.text: All these that he counts (ֹשֶמוֹנֶה) until here are neighbors of Eretz Israel.

text.title: and all those separated in that corner:

pasuk.text: those separated at the end of that corner.
Heb. עֲרָב, Arabia.

text.title: and all the kings of the allies:

pasuk.text: The allies of the Arabs.
That is ‘Babylon’ in אתבש.
Like a person who drinks too much, who vomits.
the strife of war.
מֵחֵל.
He mourns over the destruction of His house.
A cry of “Ha!” that those engaged in hard work cry out aloud to urge each other on to strengthen themselves, and those who tread the winepresses are accustomed to it.
Every expression of עֲנִיָה, is an expression of a cry with a loud voice.
He contends in judgment.
whom I incite against one another.
as the Targum renders it: מִסְיָפֵי, from the ends of.
an expression of יְלָלָה, howling.
i.e., roll in the dust (se vautrer in French).
This is a short verse; i.e., to say: and your scatterings shall come near.
That is to say: If you say, “We are important,” there are many precious glass vessels that fall, break, and are lost.
an expression of destruction, an expression related to ‘has silenced us (הֲדִמָּנוּ).’ ‘and there let us sit in silence (וְנִדְּמָה).’

text.title: He has left his hut like a young lion:

pasuk.text: The king has gone in exile from his city like a young lion that leaves his hut.

text.title: because of the wrath of the oppressing sword:

pasuk.text: drunk from wine. So did Jonathan translate. Another explanation: It is an expression of oppression (אוֹנָאָה).

text.title: In the beginning of the reign:

pasuk.text: This chapter below preceded the above chapter by four years.

text.title: And the princes of Judah heard:

pasuk.text: that the false prophets and the priests had seized Jeremiah.

text.title: at the entrance of the new gate of the Lord:

pasuk.text: Others annotated: When Jehoiachin went in exile and some of the vessels of the house of our God went with him, Nebuchadnezzar’s army breached the eastern gate, and Zedekiah subsequently repaired it and renewed it. It is therefore called ‘new.’
Who was from Maresha.
עִיִּים, heaps.
Heb. וַיְחַל, an expression of prayer.

text.title: but we are doing great harm to ourselves:

pasuk.text: if we kill him.

The one who said this did not say this. I.e., those who related the incident of Micah did not relate the incident concerning Uriah. Up to here are the words of the righteous. Now the wicked who were there arose and said, “Also a man was prophesying, etc.” Just as Uriah was killed, so shall Jeremiah be killed. In this way it is explained in Sifrei (Num. 11:7).

text.title: In the beginning of the reign of Jehoiakim:

pasuk.text: Three years prior to Nebuchadnezzar’s ascent to the throne, he prophesied about him that he would reign.
They are the thongs of the yoke that are called kongoijli (cojongles).

text.title: And you shall send them to the king of Edom:

pasuk.text: In the days of Zedekiah in the fourth year of his reign, when Nebuchadnezzar made him ruler over five kings, the king of Edom, the king of Moab, the king of the children of Ammon, etc. These five kings Nebuchadnezzar placed under the authority of Zedekiah. Fifteen years they (the bars and thongs) were on his neck, from the first year of Jehoiakim until the fourth year of Zedekiah, when Hananiah son of Azzur broke them off him.
Who will perform My will to requite My enemies.
Evil-Merodach.
Belshazzar.

text.title: until the time of his own land come:

pasuk.text: When Darius the Mede and Cyrus come and slay Belshazzar.

text.title: And to Zedekiah the king of Judah have I spoken, etc.:

pasuk.text: All this Jeremiah said to the ambassadors of the kings.

text.title: “Behold the vessels of the house of the Lord”:

pasuk.text: That were exiled with Jeconiah.
Jonathan renders: בְּסִיסַיָּא Cf.“the washbasin and its stand” (Exodus 35:16).
Heb. בַּגְּלוֹתוֹ like בְּהַגְלוֹתוֹ.
חֹרֵי, like שֹרֵי the princes of.

text.title: until the day I remember them:

pasuk.text: In the days of Cyrus, as is explained in the Book of Ezra (1:7 11).

text.title: And it came to pass in that year:

pasuk.text: When that time arrived that Nebuchadnezzar gave Zedekiah dominion over the five kings to whom Jeremiah stated his message and sent the thongs and the bars to the kings by the hand of their ambassadors.

text.title: in the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah:

pasuk.text: In the beginning of his dominion over the five kings. But it is impossible to say that it means at the beginning of his reign, since it says, “in the fourth year.” In that year, he went down to greet Nebuchadnezzar in Babylon, and Seraiah the receptionist was with him, as is stated at the end of the Book (51: 59), and he gave him dominion over the kings.

Our Sages state: Who misled Hananiah? He heard Jeremiah prophesying in the upper street, “Behold I am breaking the bow of Elam” (49: 35). And this prophecy was said in the beginning of the reign of Zedekiah, as is explained there, and since Elam is adjacent to Babylon, he stood in the lower street, and expounded. And he derived a major case from a minor one. If Elam, who came only to aid the Chaldeans, the Holy One, blessed be He, said, “Behold I am breaking the bow of Elam,” how much more is this so with the Chaldeans themselves? He came into the lower street and said: So said the Lord: I have broken the yoke of the king of Babylon, as it is in Sanhedrin (89a).
Fasse in French.
An expression of prayer. (These three lines up to “and he brought him to the prison” were not arranged by the author.)

text.title: Amen! So may the Lord do, etc.:

pasuk.text: Amen! The scholars of Aggadah say: So did he say to him: If only your words were fulfilled! I gain and you lose. I am a priest, and I eat the food hallowed in the name of Heaven if the Temple remains standing. But you are a Gibeonite, as it is written [here], “who was from Gibeon.” And you will be a slave to me, chopping wood and drawing water (Pesikta Rabbathi 27:4, Yalkut Shimoni ad loc.). But Moreh Zedek who did not explain, adopted the reason of our Sages (Sotah 41b) who learned from here that whoever flatters a wicked man will ultimately fall into his hands or into the hands of his son or into the hands of his son’s son, for Irijah, the son of Shelemiah, the son of Hananiah seized him and brought him to prison.

text.title: But, hearken now… The prophet who would prophesy for peace.:

pasuk.text: He said: I prophesy retribution. If it does not come, I am not a liar, for the Holy One, blessed be He, renounces the evil, but the prophet who prophesies for peace, etc., when the word of the prophet comes, etc., but if his word does not come, he is a liar, as it is said, “God is not a man that He should lie, etc.” (Num. 23:19). In this manner Rabbi Tanhuma (Vayera 13) expounded.

text.title: the beasts of the field have I given to him:

pasuk.text: He rode on a lion and tied a serpent on its head.
And next year you shall be buried.

text.title: in that year, in the seventh month:

pasuk.text: Is it not so that the seventh month is not of the year? Rather, he died on the day preceding Rosh Hashanah and commanded his children to hurry him after Rosh Hashanah, but not before, and they should conceal his death on that day in order to make Jeremiah’s prophecy appear false.
The mother of the king.
An expression of enticing. Cf: “The snake misled me (הֹשִיאַנִי)” (Gen. 3:13).

text.title: And you shall call Me and go:

pasuk.text: In My ways. This is an ellipsis.
Zedekiah, who has not been exiled.
Heb. הֹשֹּעָרִים, an expression of, ֹשַעֲרוּרִיָּה, “a disgraceful thing” (Hos. 6:10).
That they will reproach them, and so is every expression of ירפה in Scripture.
an expression of “roasted with fire” (Lev. 2:14).

text.title: and they committed adultery with the wives of their neighbors:

pasuk.text: As is explained in Sanhedrin (93a), “So said the Holy One, blessed be He, ‘Lie with my friend.’”
an expression of testimony (עֵדוּת).
A place name.
He wrote this to Zephaniah.
appointees.
כִּפָה
a tree trunk (ceps in French).
For you should rebuke him since he sent to us to Babylon saying, “Your exile there is long.”
like עַל-אֹשֶר because of which.
And you shall not say, Why should I write it, since they all will perish, and no one will read it, neither will anyone remember it anymore, for, “behold, days are coming, etc.”

text.title: A sound of quaking we have heard:

pasuk.text: Some interpret this as alluding to the tidings of Babylon, from which those exiled there quaked. But the Midrash Aggadah explains it as an allusion to the war of Gog and Magog.
Whether it is customary for males to give birth, so that labor pains should seize them like a woman in confinement.
like מָתְנָיו.
The day of the assassination of Belshazzar and the downfall of Babylon. Another explanation: the day of the downfall of Gog.
The yoke of the heathens will be removed from Israel.
Because of all the evils that you will see befalling Babylon in whose midst you are.
like וֹשָקֵט.

text.title: but I will chasten you in measure:

pasuk.text: according to the law of the Torah.

text.title: and I will not completely destroy you:

pasuk.text: an expression of a sweeping destruction.

text.title: Your injury is painful, your wound grievous:

pasuk.text: (Enfers in Old French).
cure. No one thinks that you will have salvation.
a cure, an expression of availing.
chastisements of cruelty. The chastisement is cruel.
This is an expression denoting an oath.
an expression of spoil, and so did Jonathan render it: וִיהוֹן עָדַיִ לַעֲדִי.
Heb. ארכה.
The Temple.
I will make them a numerous nation.

text.title: and they shall not become few in number:

pasuk.text: like יִמְעָטוּ.
lit., his mighty one.
an expression of a pledge (fermaille, aatine in French).
to war, to stop Me.

camping and dwelling an expression of “the land of the sojournings of (מְגוּרֵי) ” (Gen. 37:1), and a similar case is “and a whirling (מִתְחוֹלֵל) storm” (supra 23:19) stated in the other verse is the same as this for both of them are expressions of camping.

text.title: on the head[s] of the wicked:

pasuk.text: On the heads of the heathens.
The generation of the wilderness found favor in My eyes.
of the Egyptians the Amalekites and the Canaanites.

text.title: He [therefore] went to give Israel their resting place:

pasuk.text: When He led them to take possession of the land of their rest.
In the merit of the Patriarchs.
I, the prophet, and told me to say to the congregation of Israel, “With everlasting love have I loved you.”

text.title: Yet again will I rebuild you, then you shall be built:

pasuk.text: You had two buildings made by men. Therefore, they were destroyed. Yet again will I rebuild you, I by Myself, a third building, and you shall be built forever.
Heb. תַּעְדִּי.
in the fourth year, they shall profane their produce by redeeming it with money.

The lookouts at the tops of the lofty towers to announce with a voice heard a distance away. Another explanation: נֹצְרִים is like “He keeps (נֹצֵר) lovingkindness” (Exod. 34:7), an expression of keeping. That is to say: There is a day when they will call those who kept the Torah and say, “Rise…” And so did Jonathan render: There are many days and much goodness that is destined to come to the righteous who kept My Torah from days of old.

text.title: and shout at the head of the nations:

pasuk.text: On the lofty towers, so that they should hear from afar.

text.title: the blind and the lame amongst them:

pasuk.text: Even the staggering ones among them I will not reject.
Through prayer and repentance.
(separant in French, separating.
They will gather like a river.
Heb. דָשֶן.

text.title: A voice is heard on high:

pasuk.text: A voice is heard in the height of the world, the voice of the house of Israel weeping over Jeremiah the prophet when Nebuzaradan sent him from Ramah to return after the exiles to Gedaliah son of Ahikam, as is stated in this Book (below ch. 39).

The Midrash Aggadah states (see Lam. Rabbah Proem 24) that the Patriarchs and the Matriarchs went to appease the Holy One blessed be He concerning the sin of Manasseh who placed an image in the Temple but He was not appeased. Rachel entered and stated before Him “O Lord of the Universe, whose mercy is greater, Your mercy or the mercy of a flesh and blood person? You must admit that Your mercy is greater. Now did I not bring my rival into my house? For all the work that Jacob worked for my father he worked only for me. When I came to enter the nuptial canopy, they brought my sister, and it was not enough that I kept my silence, but I gave her my password. You, too, if Your children have brought Your rival into Your house, keep Your silence for them.” He said to her, “You have defended them well. There is reward for your deed and for your righteousness, that you gave over your password to your sister.”
(Konpljjet in O.F.), an expression of “who will lament for you (יָנוּד) ?” (above 15:5).
With pains, You, the Holy One, blessed be He.
(fut aiguillones in O.F.), was goaded, an expression of “an ox-goad (מַלְמַד הַבָּקָר) ” (Judges 3:31). I was like an ungoaded calf in the beginning. Therefore, I sinned against You.

text.title: I have completely changed my mind:

pasuk.text: I regret my abominations.

text.title: I had been brought to know myself:

pasuk.text: That I thought of myself that I was treacherous, (aparsoujjge in O. F.).
That my enemies can reproach me for the sins of my youth.

text.title: “Is Ephraim a son who is dear to me?”:

pasuk.text: These are the words of the Shechinah. That is to say, He is complaining, “And as for Me, I have a change of heart to have pity. Is he My dear son (as one who has but one son, whose every wish he grants him)?”
(Esbaniement in O.F.)

Every time that I speak of him. And the Midrash Leviticus Rabbah (2:3) explains: It is enough My speech (דַּי דִבּוּרִי) with which I endowed him, that I taught him My Torah, for Me to have mercy on him.
Signs in the good ways of your ancestors.

small palms (תְּמָרִים) planted for a sign on the way. And the simple interpretation of the verse is. Make signs to know the way you traversed from Eretz Israel to Babylon, so that you will return by that road; that is to say that you will surely return from there.

text.title: the road upon which you went:

pasuk.text: The “kethib” is הָלָכְתִּי, “I went,” and everywhere that you went I went with you Jonathan, however, renders. place “tamrurim” for yourself: Pray with embittered spirit, deriving תַּמְרוּרִים from מַר bitter. (And Menahem [Machbereth p. 119] explained תַּמְרוּרִים as an expression of raising up, and so he explained וְתִמְרוֹת “raising of smoke” (Joel 3:3). In some editions, this is missing.)

will you hide from Me, that you are ashamed to return to Me because of your way? Behold, something new has been created on earth, that a woman shall go after a man to seek him that he should marry her. This is an expression of “and I will go around (וַאֲסוֹבְבָה) in the city; I will seek, etc.” (Song 3:2). And in the name of Rabbi Judah the Preacher I heard: A woman shall turn around to become a man. I gave you like a daughter, who receives a tenth of the property of her father, seven nations out of seventy. Ultimately, you shall take everything like a son, a male, who inherits everything.
So said Jeremiah, “All this time I was sleeping deeply while perceiving the prophecy of retribution, but with this prophecy I awoke from my deep sleep.”
Heb. עָרְבָה.

text.title: seed of man and seed of beasts:

pasuk.text: The good and the foolish of them, I will sow all of them to be My seed. Seed of man and seed of beasts. Jonathan renders. I will set them up (our edition: I will increase them) like people and I will make them succeed like a beast, whose iniquities are not visited upon her.
A fruit that is not yet ripe, and it sets the teeth on edge.

text.title: And the teeth of the children shall be set on edge…:

pasuk.text: The children for the fathers’ iniquity.
(esclarzir in Prov. or eclaircir in O.F., eclairer in Modern French), to brighten, and so did Jonathan render: לְאַנְהָרָא, to illuminate.
He breaks the sea, moves it and “boils” it, and it becomes wrinkles. Cf.“my skin became wrinkled (רָגַע)” (Job 7:5).
“He would not move away (יָמִיש)” (Exod. 13:22).

text.title: If the heavens… will be measured:

pasuk.text: How much is their altitude.
That is to say that just as they can neither be measured nor fathomed so will Israel not be rejected because of all that they sinned.
The valley where the bodies of the camp of Sennacherib fell.

The place where the ashes are poured out, which was outside Jerusalem, they will add to the city and include all this within its walls. Now this prophecy relates to the future, to the final redemption, since it did not take place in the time of the Second Temple.
(Kanpanjje in O.F.) (campagne in Modern French, open country.
an expression of a siege (מָצוֹר).
an expression of “the prison” (בֵּיתהַמֹּשְמָר).
The remembrance of all mankind. That is death.
He did not say this to Zedekiah but Scripture explained why he imprisoned him and then returned to its first statement to explain what the word was that came to Jeremiah.
By Divine command.
The deed of the sale.
With its signature as it was signed according so the law and the statute.

Which was confirmed in the court by word of its witnesses, and the judges wrote and signed a judicial confirmation. This is the confirmation of the deeds to make the matter open and publicized lest the witnesses die, and our Rabbis explained this concerning a plain, open document and a folded one in Baba Bathra (160b).

text.title: in the presence of Hanamel my uncle:

pasuk.text: And until now, he calls him “my uncle’s son.” Perhaps there were two. Otherwise, I do not know what it means. Some are inclined to say that Hanamel was both Jeremiah’s uncle and his uncle’s son; e.g. Reuben married the daughter of his brother Simon, and she bore him Jemuel, and Simon had already begotten Jamin. Hence, Jamin is Jemuel’s uncle, since he is his mother’s brother, and also his uncle’s son, since he is the son of Simon, Jemuel’s father’s brother. This is, however, not the method of expression, for we do not find anywhere in the Bible, that the mother’s brother is called an uncle.
Do not say that I am concealing them for nothing since everyone is going into exile.
They will ultimately purchase houses.
Nothing is hidden; hence You know that we are destined to be exiled, so why did You tell me to buy a field?

text.title: and requites the iniquity of the fathers in the bosom:

pasuk.text: Of this generation who follow their ancestors in their evil way.
But he did not say, “and awesome.” He said. Heathens are dancing in His Temple. Where then are His awesome deeds? In Tractate Yoma (69b).

And in other people. Another explanation: Signs that were equal for Israel and for the Egyptians. How so?“And there was the cloud and the darkness, and it illuminated the night” (Exodus 14:20). That guardian angel that served darkness for the Egyptians, served light for the Israelites Midrash Aggadah (source unknown). And Jonathan renders: And for Israel You performed wonders among people.

text.title: then You caused… to come upon them:

pasuk.text: You caused to happen to them, an expression of a happening (מִקְרֶה).
Evil upon it has come to pass (lit., has been and has come).
Of what avail is the field to me?
Are future events concealed from Me?

text.title: since the day they built it:

pasuk.text: On the day that the Temple was founded, Solomon married Pharaoh’s daughter.
lit., and teaching them. This is a participle, (apprenant in French).
with mercy from wherever I have driven them with My anger.
in the prison.

text.title: So said the Lord, the Maker thereof:

pasuk.text: Who makes this.

text.title: Call Me and I will answer you:

pasuk.text: to inform you of future events.
laid up in My heart to perform them.

text.title: that are demolished for the mounds:

pasuk.text: To make mounds of them, mounds piled up high which the city dwellers build to ascend the mounds to wage war from upon them with the Chaldeans.
To strengthen the wall against those who slay with the sword.

text.title: and to fill them with the corpses of the men:

pasuk.text: And the houses that they demolished they make into graves for the corpses of those killed within the city.

text.title: and that which I have hidden, etc.:

pasuk.text: So said the Lord: Behold, I will bring it, etc.
a blessing (salud in O.F., salut in modern French), a greeting.
Heb. נְוֵה רֹעִים.
Israel will come and go under the hands of a king who walks at their head.

text.title: There shall not be cut off:

pasuk.text: permanently, but if it is discontinued, it will ultimately be reinstated.
There shall not be cut off from them seed fit to offer up a burnt-offering or to burn a meal-offering.

text.title: If you break My covenant with the day:

pasuk.text: If you can break My covenant that I formed with the day and with the night to be in their time, which I formed with Noah and his sons, “And day and night shall not cease” (Gen. 8:22).
Viz. royalty and the priesthood.

text.title: and they make My people despise:

pasuk.text: And with these words, they cause My people to despise being a nation to Me.
According to these words of theirs, that they teach them to say that the Holy One, blessed be He, will no longer return from His anger, and repentance will not avail them.

If it is possible that the covenant that I formed with day and night to be in their time should be abolished, and if it is possible for the statutes of heaven and earth to be abolished as though I had not placed them, also the seed of Jacob, etc. Our Sages, however, expounded it in regard to the covenant of the Torah and circumcision, to derive from here that because of them heaven and earth were created. But this Midrash does not fit the sequence of the verses.

Our Sages stated that Nebuchadnezzar died during his lifetime (Moed Katan 28b), for all the days of Nebuchadnezzar his prisoners were not freed from their imprisonment, and when Nebuchadnezzar died, Zedekiah emerged from the prison. He died the next day and was buried with pomp.

text.title: and with the burnings of your forefathers:

pasuk.text: So was their custom, to burn for the kings their bier and the utensils they used.

text.title: after King Zedekiah had made a covenant:

pasuk.text: In the seventh year of his reign. So we learned it in Seder Olam (ch. 26): “And it came to pass in the seventh year… men came of the elders of Judah (sic) to inquire of the Lord” (Ezekiel 20:1). They said to Ezekiel, ‘The slave of a priest whom his owner soldwhat is the ruling regarding whether he may eat of the priest’s due?’ That is to say, because they wanted to say that they should not be punished for infracting the commandment by returning the slaves.

text.title: behold I proclaim freedom to you:

pasuk.text: from Me, that I am not your master to save you, and you shall be free to the sword and to the famine.

text.title: when they cut the calf in two:

pasuk.text: Whey they returned and forced them to be slaves, they all made a covenant to rebel against the Omnipresent and cut a calf in two and passed between its parts to rebel against Him, and that was a strong covenant and a final one, saying, So shall the one who transgresses be cut and divided.

text.title: who have gone up away from you:

pasuk.text: because of the army of Pharaoh that came out of Egypt, as is explained in this Book (37:5).
that Pharaoh’s army return to his land, and the Chaldeans return upon you.

text.title: to the house of the Rechabites:

pasuk.text: The sons of Jonadab the son of Rechab, and they were of the sons of Jethro.
The prophet of the Lord.
Heb. שמר הסף. Jonathan renders: אמרכּלא (tresorier in French,) a treasurer.

text.title: but you shall dwell in tents:

pasuk.text: in the deserts where you dwell. They had no share in the land since they were the children of proselytes.

text.title: And it came to pass when Nebuchadrezzar… came up:

pasuk.text: Perforce we came to the city. Therefore, we are now dwelling in houses.
in the jail.
That is the Eastern Gate; so did Jonathan translate.
Perhaps he will hear.
Heb. חצרה, equivalent to אל החצר. Every word that requires a ‘lammed’ in the beginning Scripture placed a ‘heh’ at its end.

Heb. האח. Our Rabbis (Shabbath 21a) defined it as wood, called so because they burn with brotherhood. (That is to say that they are ignited one from the other, like brothers, who benefit each other. Omitted in other editions.) And according to its simple meaning, it appears that it is a vessel upon which they kindle fire before the princes.

Our Rabbis (Moed Katan 26a) stated. This was the Scroll of Lamentations. They read before him, (1:1) “How…(:2) She weeps… (ibid. 3) Judah has been exiled…(ibid. 4) The roads of Zion are mournful.” Despite all this, he was not troubled. He said, “I am the king over the survivors.” As soon as he read (ibid. 5), Her adversaries have become the head, “ he said,” From now on, I am [no longer] the king." Immediately, he rent it with a scribe’s razor.
Heb. יקרעה, like קְרָעָה.
Heb. הפגעו, supplicated.

At first, there were three alphabetical acrostics: (Lam. ch. 1) “O how… remained,” (2) “How… brought darkness,” (4) “How dim… has become.” And he added to it, (3) “I am the man,” in which every letter is tripled.

Since from now on, i.e., from this point, he comes to tell and to say that the retributions that he prophesied until now were fulfilled, he started to tell in this manner, that when the time of the visitation, when the days drew near that the words should be fulfilled, another king reigned over Judah instead of Coniah the son of Jehoiakim, etc.

text.title: And Jeremiah was coming and going among the people:

pasuk.text: When Zedekiah assumed the throne, he gave an order and they freed him from the jail where Jehoiakim had imprisoned him, for Zedekiah was a righteous man and the people of his generation were wicked, whereas Jehoiakim was a wicked man and the people of his generation were righteous.

text.title: Now Pharaoh’s army had left Egypt:

pasuk.text: to aid Judah.

text.title: is returning to his land Egypt:

pasuk.text: They were coming in ships, and the Holy One, blessed be He, signaled to the sea and caused a type of bottles and flasks (i.e., inflated) resembling human skins to float on it. They said to each other, What is this? They replied, These are our forefathers, whom the forefathers of these whom we are going to aid, drowned. They immediately returned to their land.

text.title: to share [land] from there among the people:

pasuk.text: Jonathan [renders]: To share his inheritance among the people, and as long as the Chaldeans were besieging it, he did not leave it, for he prayed that it should not be taken.

text.title: and there was the captain of the guard:

pasuk.text: Appointed to guard so that no man should leave the city to make peace with the Chaldeans.

text.title: the son of Shelemiah the son of Hananiah:

pasuk.text: That is Hananiah the son of Azzur. He was his grandson, and for the following reason Scripture traced his lineage, [viz.] to teach that whoever flatters a wicked man eventually falls into his hands or into the hands of his son or into the hands of his grandson, and Jeremiah flattered him, for he said to him, “Amen! (28:6) [So may the Lord do.] May the Lord fulfil your words” (Sotah 41b). And [according to] the Midrash Aggadah, Hananiah commanded his son, "See that I am dying because of Jeremiah, and he made me a liar in my prophecy. If you can cause him to stumble, cause him to stumble. And his son commanded his son also in that manner, and when the time came, he caused him to stumble.
Jonathan renders: within the cells. There were cells before that prison.

text.title: from the street of the bakers:

pasuk.text: Heb. מחוץ, from the street of the bakers. Cf: “And you shall make streets (וחצות) for yourself in Damascus” (I Kings 20:34).

text.title: and he shall have his life as prey:

pasuk.text: His life shall be saved, as if had “plundered” his soul; just as a man profits from plundering booty, so this person will profit [by saving] his life.
(a lacher in O.F.), an expression of weakness.
Heb. יוּכַל, like יָכוֹל, since he is weakening the hands of, etc.
lit. the pit Malchiah.
Baruch the son of Neriah.

Zedekiah. Just as a Cushite is different in his skin, so was Zedekiah different in his righteousness, from all his generation (Moed Katan 16b). And there is a Midrash that expounds “the Cushite,” as referring to Baruch (Sifrei ibid.).
Heb. סריס, a great man.

text.title: He would have died in his place, etc.:

pasuk.text: If they had left him in his place, he would have died by himself in the famine, but they have done harm to bring his death closer.
Since they were weakened by the famine, all of them were required.
Heb. בלוי סחבות, worn out garments, that are dragged.
Heb. והמלחים, an expression of decay. Cf.“shall vanish (נמלחוּ) like smoke” (Isa. 51: 6).
So that the ropes should not harm you.
Heb. אצילות, aisseles in French.
I do not know where it is. Perhaps it is in the Israelites’ Court. The appellation “third” is to say that the hel [the wall surrounding the Temple Court], and the Women’s Court are before it.
Heb. דֹאֵג.
[Lest] the Chaldeans [deliver me] into the hands of the Jews, saying, Your king shall be your slave since you have made peace with us first.
[i.e.,] the Jews [will mock me] (engregier in O.F.), complain.
[lit. the men of your peace,] the false prophets, who told you that you would not be caught.
Heb. בבץ, mire, an expression as in (Job 8:11): “Can the rush shoot up without mire (בצה) ?”

text.title: and this city you shall burn with fire:

pasuk.text: It is as though you are burning it with your hands for you are causing it.

text.title: And all the officers of the king of Babylon came and sat in the middle gate, etc.:

pasuk.text: [This] tells [us] that here the above prophecy, “And they will come and place, each one his throne at the entrance of the gates of Jerusalem, etc.” (1:15) was fulfilled.

Heb. בשער התוך. Jonathan renders: in the middle gate, the gate of the Temple court, the Nicanor Gate, the Eastern Gate, and it is between the gate of the Women’s Court and the gate of the Temple proper. And our Rabbis (Sanh. 103a) said: The gate where the halachoth were decided (מחתכים). Concerning them, Scripture says. “The place of judgment there is wickedness” (Ecc. 3:16).

text.title: by way of the king’s garden:

pasuk.text: He had a cave from his house to the plains of Jericho, and he went out at night by way of the cave. What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do to fulfill “And I will spread My net over him” (Ezek. 12:13)? He prepared a deer before the Chaldeans walking on the roof the cave outside the city, and they ran after it to seize it, and it ran up to the entrance of the cave, and they saw Zedekiah going out of the cave.
Why did you transgress the oath?

text.title: and… all the nobles of Judah:

pasuk.text: These are the Sanhedrin, because they had annulled the oath.
The synagogues.
Heb. ויגבים, fields to till. Every יגיבה is an expression of digging (a fosser in French), to dig.
Heb. רבי, like שָּׂרֵי.

text.title: to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam:

pasuk.text: who defected to the Chaldeans in compliance with Jeremiah’s orders, and when the city was taken, he appointed him governor over those remaining there.

text.title: and they shall be before you on that day:

pasuk.text: And the words shall be before you, for you shall see them fulfilled.

text.title: into the hand[s] of the men:

pasuk.text: into the hand[s] of the Chaldeans.

What is stated at the end of the section (42: 7): “And it was at the end of ten days that the word of the Lord came etc.,” but he first wrote on account of what it was said to him. And the Midrash Aggadah in Lamentations Rabbah (Proem 34): What was the word? “And return to Gedaliah.” He said to him: Either you go down with them and I will remain (?) here, or you remain here and I will go down with them. He replied: If I go down with them, what will I help them? Rather, let their Creator go down with them, for He will help them exceedingly.

Where he went into exile by himself with them. He would see a group [of youths] joined by a collar and would put his neck between them, etc., as is stated in Pesikta of the Haftarah Divrei Yirmiyahu (p. 113). For it is impossible to say that Nebuzaradan put him in chains since Nebuchadnezzar commanded him, “Do him no harm” (above 39:12).
Heb. באזקים, ceps in French, fetters.
Why are you troubled about them? Did you not prophesy to them and they did not hearken? As it is stated in Pesikta d’Rav Kahana (p. 113a).

Heb. פתחתיך, an expression related to “And he untied (ויפתח) the camels” (Gen. 24.32). And so did Jonathan render: Behold, now I have untied you. But Menahem (p. 147) interpreted all of them as an expression of actual opening (פתיחה).

text.title: But he would still not return:

pasuk.text: Despite this, he did not wish to return. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, “And return to Gedaliah,” who was appointed over the remaining poor people. They, too, need you, like the rest of the exiles.
Heb. ארחה ומשאת. Jonathan renders: מתנן וּנבזבן.
Heb. וקיץ, dried figs.
They were jealous of him that he took a high position.

text.title: to bring to the house of the Lord:

pasuk.text: When they left home, they were unaware of the destruction of the Temple, and en route, they heard of it, and rent their clothing and shaved their beards.
An expression [denoting] laceration.

Heb. ביד, [lit. by the hand of Gedaliah]. Since he should have heeded the counsel of Johanan the son of Kareah, and he did not heed, Scripture accounts it for him as though they had been slain by him.
[By the pool of great waters.]

In the sojourning place that David gave to Chimham the son of Barzilai the Gileadite when he returned from the war of Absalom, as it is stated in the Book of Samuel (II 19:39): “Chimham shall go over with me.”
which the lookouts sound to warn the people.

text.title: and hide them in the mortar:

pasuk.text: Heb. במלט. This ‘mem’ is a defective radical in the word, like מקום, a place, מעמד, a stand, מעשה, a deed, and its root is לט, cf.“he wrapped (וילט) his face” (I Kings 19:13). Envelop them in the mortar in the framework.
(Envolopemant in O.F)
Heb. שפרירו, his tent, and a similar case is [found] in Job 26:13: “By His breath, He made the heavens a tent (שפרה).”

text.title: and he shall wrap up the land of Egypt:

pasuk.text: He shall wrap up all its plunder and leave, as a shepherd wraps up and rolls his garment and casts it over his shoulder when he leads his flock before him.

The altars that those who proselytized in the days of Hezekiah had made there Sennacherib’s captives whom he brought from Cush and from Egypt before Jerusalem on the day of his downfall, as it is stated “On that day there shall be five cities in the land of Egypt speaking the language of Canaan and swearing to the Lord of Hosts one of which will be called ‘the city of Heres’” (Isa. 19.18). Jonathan renders: The city of Beth-shemesh, which is destined to be destroyed, will be said to be one of them.
Their hearts were not crushed because of their evil.

Jeremiah and Baruch returned from there, for Nebuchadnezzar exiled them when the land of Egypt was delivered into his hand in the twenty-seventh year of his reign (Ezek. 29:17). So we learned in Seder Olam (ch. 26).
Without their knowledge.
Heb. כונים להעצבה, molds in the shape of idols (idols in the shape of a young lady as above ch. 22:28).

text.title: And He could no longer bear:

pasuk.text: Heb. ולא יוּכַל, like ולא יָכוֹל, and He could not.
Heb. פרעה חפרע, rendered by Jonathan as פרעֹה תבירה, the broken Pharaoh, and this ‘heth’ serves instead of a ‘heh.’

text.title: but I have found no rest:

pasuk.text: Heb. ומנוחה. The Shechinah has not rested upon me to prophesy. Cf.“And the spirit rested (ותנח) upon them” (Num. 12:26). “Why am I different from the disciples of the prophets? Joshua served Moses and the Holy Spirit rested upon him. Elisha served Elijah and the Holy Spirit rested upon him. Why am I different?”

text.title: and it is all the land:

pasuk.text: that is being judged with this uprooting and tearing down.

text.title: And you seek great things for yourself?:

pasuk.text: [“Great things” means] prophecies. Cf. “Please tell me all the great things etc.” (II Kings 8:4).“Call to me… and I will tell you great, etc,” (above 33:3). The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: If there is no vineyard, there is no fence, and if there are no sheep, there is no shepherd. I reveal Myself to the prophets only in the merit of Israel. We learned this in the Mechilta, in the beginning.
Heb. מגן. It is made of leather, and it is boiled, and when he goes forth to battle, he anoints it with oil.
Heb. וצנה, [made] of wood, in the likeness of our shields.
Heb. מרקו. Cf.“It shall be scoured (וּמֹרַק) and rinsed” (Lev. 6:21), (forbir in O.F., to furbish).
The Egyptians.
[They were] no longer freed to stand in battle; they had no free time.

text.title: Who… would come up like the Nile:

pasuk.text: Who was wont to bring up troops around him like the waters of a river, to flood its environs.

text.title: would come up like the Nile:

pasuk.text: Was accustomed to coming up.
Heb. אֹבִידָה, like אֲאַבֵּד.
Heb. והתהללו, an expression of folly.

text.title: and its thirst shall be quenched:

pasuk.text: Heb. ורותה, an expression of satiety. [Another interpretation: It] is an expression of drunkenness; cf. שֵּׁכַר, strong drink, which we translate מְרַוֵי.
For Pharaoh marched on Nebuchadnezzar in Carchemish, and there he fell and his mighty men were slain, and he fled from the battle.

text.title: a mighty man has stumbled upon a mighty man:

pasuk.text: When they were fleeing they would stumble over each other.
This was a second blow, [viz.] that Nebuchadnezzar laid Egypt waste in the twenty-seventh year of his reign (Ezek. 29:17), as we learned in Seder Olam (ch. 26).
for the war. והכן means “and prepare.”

Heb. נסחף. Your mighty men have been swept away and have slid. Cf.“sweeping (סֹחֵף) rain” (Prov. 28:3);“His field has been inundated (נסתחפה)” (Kethuboth 1:6). Menahem (Machbereth p. 126) classified it as an expression of complete destruction, and so did he classify סחף מטר. Dunash, however, interprets מטר סחף like מטר סועף, cutting rain. Cf.“Lops off (מְסָעֵף) the branches with a saw” (Isa. 10:33).
The Holy One, blessed be He, Who pushed him down, made many stumbling blocks for him.
Heb. נפל [lit. fell]. They joined one another, saying, Arise and let us go back to our own people, whence we came to wage war.
Heb. חרב. Jonathan renders: The sword of the enemy, which is like intoxicating wine. היונה. An expression of wine (יין). Another interpretation: It is an expression of oppression (אונאה).
In the battle, they proclaimed publicly a reproachful byword.

text.title: “Pharaoh, king of Egypt, who made a lot of noise”:

pasuk.text: Who would raise the sound of his noise, the noises to boast with his armies.

text.title: has allowed the appointed time to pass by:

pasuk.text: For he had appointed a set time to go forth and wage war, and he did not go forth, and the day of the appointed time passed by.

text.title: that as sure as Tabor is among the mountains:

pasuk.text: Just as it is a true fact that Tabor is fast among the mountains and Mount Carmel is by the sea, so is it true that this thing shall come upon Egypt.
When a person embarks on a journey, he prepares for himself a flask and an earthenware cup with which to drink.
Heb. ונצחה, an expression of desolation (ציה).
A beautiful kingdom.
peoples that kill [acc. to Jonathan]. קֶרֶץ is an expression of cutting. Cf.“I… was cut (קֹרצתי) out of clay” (Job 33: 6).
From Babylon.
Heb. שְׂכִרֶיהָ, her princes. Cf.“with the great razor (הַשְׂכִירָה) ” (Isa. 7: 20).
(kopla in O.F., couple in modern French).
Turned their back to seek to flee.

text.title: Its voice shall go like [that of] the snake:

pasuk.text: The “snake” comes to teach us about Egypt but ends by learning. For we learn from here that when the Holy One, blessed be He, said to the serpent, “You shall walk on your belly” (Gen. 3:14), He severed his feet, and his voice went to the end of the world. So we learned in the ‘Thirty-two Methods of Rabbi Eliezer the son of Rabbi Jose the Galilean’ (Method 12).

text.title: for they will march with an army:

pasuk.text: against her.

text.title: They will cut down her forest:

pasuk.text: They have power to cut down her forest.
[lit. it shall not be fathomed, i.e.,] the number of their host.
Heb. אל אמון, [lit. to Amon,] upon Amon, upon the prince Amon. There are some that are an expression of greatness. Cf.“Are you greater than the greatness of No (מִנֹא אָמוֹן) ?” (Nahum 3:8).
The great Alexandria (les seigneurs d’Alexandria in O.F.).
At the end of forty years, as Ezekiel stated (29:1 3ff.).
The righteous men who were in Egypt, who were exiled there against their will.
With sparing justice, little by little.
Heb. ונקה [lit. clean,] an expression of sweeping and destroying, and Jonathan too rendered it an expression of destroying.
Heb. אל פלישתים [lit.] to the Philistines.

When Nebuchadnezzar besieged Jerusalem in the tenth year of Zedekiah, Pharaoh’s army came forth from Egypt, and the Chaldeans withdrew from Jerusalem. Pharaoh heard, invaded Gaza and returned to his land. In Seder Olam (ch. 26).
Heb. שעטת. There is no similar [word in Scripture]. And Jonathan rendered it: from the steps.

text.title: from the noise of his chariots:

pasuk.text: Heb. מרעש לרכבו [lit.] from the noise to his chariots.
The wheels of his chariots.

text.title: fathers did not turn to sons:

pasuk.text: to save them.

text.title: to cut off from Tyre and Zidon:

pasuk.text: The Philistines were aiding them against their enemies.
(Isls in O.F.)
Heb. נדמתה.
Will you tear your flesh in mourning and in weeping?
Which the Holy One, Blessed be He, brings to the world.
Heb. הרגעי, an expression of מרגועַ rest.
A place name.
These are place names, and according to their names he mentions their retribution.
Heb. תִּדֹּמִי.
Jonathan [renders]: Her governors, younger than the kings.
It is a place name, the ascent of a mountain.

The tower of Aro’er that is made in the desert, and there is no civilization around it except tent dwellers, and a tower standing without an inhabited region appears as ruins. So did Jonathan render it. (See Isaiah 17:2, Commentary Digest.) But Menahem (Machbereth Menahem p. 137) explained כּערוער as the name of a tree of the forest trees.

Heb. ציץ. Give wings to Moab. Every appendage that hangs or protrudes from man or beast is called ציץ. Cf.“And it shall be to you for fringes (לציצית) ” (Num. 15: 39);“And He took me by the locks (בציצית) of my head” (Ezek. 8: 3).

Heb. נצא תצא. For with flight and haste you shall go forth into exile, and נָצֹא will be of the conjugation of נוֹצָה, a feather. So did Menahem (Machbereth Menahem p. 151) classify it, and so “Yea, they fled away (נָצוּ) and wandered” (Lam. 4:15). Jonathan renders: Remove the crown from Moab. Give others the crown of Moab.
The work of the destruction of Moab, which is the mission of the Omnipresent.
Heb. נָמָר.
Heb. ציעים, those who pour. Cf.“What must be poured out (צֹעֶה) hastened to be opened” (Isa. 51:14). That is the moving of the bowels by pouring.
Heb. נבליהם [lit. their jars], the Moabites’ flasks.
Heb. ינפצו, they shall break. Cf.“How were they regarded as earthen jars (לְנִבְלֵי) (Lam. 4:2). Also,” Every bottle (נֵבֶל) will be filled with wine" (supra 13.12).
in whom they trusted.
The golden calf.
Heb. נדו, an expression of lamentation. Cf.“and do not lament (תָּנוּד) for him.”

text.title: ask those who have fled and escaped:

pasuk.text: Ask those who flee and escape from Moab, what transpired, if anyone escaped from being destroyed
Retribution has come.
Give him to drink [the cup of] weakness until he is drunk.
Just as Israel was derided by him [i.e., Moab].

Heb. תתנודד. You would shake your head and scoff at their destruction. Another interpretation: For because of your words about him, that you would sing about his destruction, you are going to wander (מתנודד) to go out into exile. And so did Jonathan render: Because you spoke many words about them, therefore you shall wander.

text.title: in the sides of the mouth of a pit:

pasuk.text: The place where the water passes under the high embankments of the bank of a wadi, and when the wadi is diminished, the pit is found to be empty, and the dove nests in one of the sides of the pit. And when the wadi increases, it inundates the nest and she wanders from there. So I heard, but Jonathan did not render in that manner, [but:] Be like a dove, that leaves the opening of the dovecote and goes down and rests at the bottom of a pit.

text.title: his wrath, and it is not so:

pasuk.text: His hatred of Israel is not in truth or in justice.
Heb. בדיו [lit.] his branches.
They did not recompense justly the seed of Abraham, who fought with the kings and saved Lot, their ancestor.
A city of the land of Moab.
Moaning like moaning doves.

text.title: From the weeping of Jazar I will weep for you:

pasuk.text: When this prophecy was said, Jazer had already been destroyed, and that was near Moab.
I will weep for you, similar to that other weeping [i.e., for Jazer], for you will be destroyed just like [Jazer].
It was a land of vineyards.
Since he compared them to a grape vine, he compared their mighty men to the tendrils of the vine.
i.e., they went into exile.
Heb. קיצך, an expression of dried figs, but קִצֵ (51:13), an expression of (קץ), an end, has no ‘yud’ and its ‘tzaddi’ has a ‘dagesh.’
Heb. ונאספה, shall be ended that it shall not be seen.
grapes with a voice of shouting, “Hedad!” with joy as they were wont to do.

text.title: The shouting shall be no shouting:

pasuk.text: The shouting that they will cry will not be the first shouting, but the shouting of fleeing the sword.
Heb. עגלתשלישיה, mighty province.
יתרתעשה. Because they dealt haughtily, they perished.
Heb. גדדת.
Wail about her and say, “How was she dismayed?”

text.title: like an eagle he shall soar:

pasuk.text: [i. e.,] the enemy [shall swoop] upon Moab.
Heb. ידאה, shall fly.
Heb. הקריות, the name of the city.
These are two hard things, one next to the other, for fright causes him to flee, and the pit is ready to fall into. פַּחַת is (fosse in French) a pit.
which is high and has a shadow.
Those who were fleeing [stood] to rest in the shadow since they had no more strength to flee.
Heb. מבין, from the city of Sihon. Cf.“the city of (בֶּן) Reuben” in Joshua (15:6).

text.title: and the crown of the head:

pasuk.text: Heb. וקדקד, (estrit in Provencal or estrif in O.F. [to fight]) and Menahem (Machbereth Menahem p. 158) classified it as an expression of a spring (מָקוֹר) and Jonathan rendered: יַקִּירֵי the esteemed ones, an expression of יְקָר, esteem.
Heb. בני שאון, those who would raise their voice with boasting.
The ‘beth’ is weak [without a ‘dagesh’], and the ‘heh’ is vowelized with a ‘hataph-pattah,’ which is an expression of wonder [interrogative].
The deity of the children of Ammon is named Malcam, as it is stated: “And to Milcom, the abomination of the children of Ammon” (II Kings 23: 13), an expression of מֶלֶ, a king.
Ai, that is near it, [has been spoiled,] and it is of the land of Ammon.
Rabbah of the children of Ammon.

Heb. והתשוטטנה בגדרות. Jonathan renders: ואתהמכוּן בסיעָן, mobilize in companies. He interprets והתשוטטנה as an expression of armies that run to and fro (משוטטים); and גדרות is an expression of sheepcotes full of flocks, and can be interpreted as “and roll in the dung of the sheepcotes,” an expression of contempt. [Onkelos translates:] “And Esau despised” (Gen. 25:34), ושט עשו.
Heb. תתהללי (vanter in French).
That your land is a land of valleys and lack of rainfall is not harmful to it since the sun does not penetrate into it.
A misfortune of an overabundance of rain shall come upon it until the water will flow in the valley and inundate the roots of the grain So did Menahem [Machbereth Menahem p. 77] explain it.
Anyone who can hurry and flee.
The term [לנדד] derives from נע ונד, “a wanderer and an exile” (Gen. 4:14).
Edom is in the south of Eretz Israel, as it is stated.“And your south side shall be from the desert of Zin close by the side of Edom” (Num. 34:3).
Heb. מבנים, from this generation.
Heb. נסרחה.
Heb. הפנו. Vacate this place. This is an expression of “And they shall clear out (וּפְּנוּ) the house” (Lev. 14:36).
to hide in the secret valleys. נֻסוּ הָפְנוּ הֶעְמִקוּ are all in the imperative form.

text.title: If vintagers have come upon you, etc.:

pasuk.text: I have exposed Esau, etc. I have heard tidings, etc. On this order, Obadiah prophesied concerning Edom, but since one watchword is passed to many prophets, but no two prophets prophesy under the same watchword, they differ in several words.

text.title: will they not leave over gleaning grapes?:

pasuk.text: This is the interrogative. Yet the spoilers who came upon you left over nothing for you.

Heb. חשפתי, uncovered. Cf.“the exposure (מַחְשֹף) of the white” (Gen. 30:37). And you delivered the survivors of Israel in order that no one remain of them, as it is stated: “Neither should you have delivered his survivors” (Obadiah 1:14).
He will seek to hide but will be unable.
whom you have orphaned of Israel.

text.title: those who do not deserve to drink:

pasuk.text: For they were not brothers to Israel, and if they harmed them, they do not deserve the death sentence like you.

text.title: that Bozrah shall become desolation, reproach, waste, and a curse:

pasuk.text: Bozrah was one of the cities of Moab, but because it raised up a king for Edom, as the matter is stated, “And Jobab the son of Zerah from Bozrah” (Gen. 36:33), it will suffer with them.
For they have no king who is the son of a king. It was not their custom to set up a king the son of a king.

Heb. תפלצתך, an expression of haste, for you hurried and were hasty to arouse your hatred for your brother. And there are some who translate this as an expression of fright (פַּלָצוּת), and there are some who translate it as an expression of an image (מפלצת).
to harm them.
Heb. שכני, like שׁוֹכֵן.
תפשי, like תּופֵשׂ, and the ‘yud’ is superfluous in it.
that ascends from the heights of the Jordan, which is a place frequented by lions, as Jonathan renders, so shall the enemy ascend upon the strong dwelling place.

text.title: for I will bring the moment:

pasuk.text: Heb. ארגיעה.

text.title: I will hasten him away from her:

pasuk.text: Suddenly and successfully he shall destroy her and return in a brief movement to his place. But I say that אריצנוּ מעליה means: I will hasten him over her, that he shall overpower her and be over her. Cf.“Above (ממעל) the expanse” (Gen. 1:7);“Above (ממעל) for Him” (Isa. 6: 2);“Over (מֵעַל) his garments” (I Sam. 17:39).
He whom I have chosen to wreak My vengeance, I will appoint over her. 7

text.title: and who will appoint Me a time:

pasuk.text: For bartle, to wage war with Me?
A king.
An expression of ‘indeed.’
Heb. יסחבום.
The despised of the nations, and our Rabbis [Yoma 10] expounded that it refers to Persia, who was the youngest of Japheth’s sons.
Heb. ישים, an expression of desolation (שממה).
